NOT GUILTY, being insane at the time of the commission of the offence .
Before Mr. Baron Vaughan.

177.
EDWARD COLLINS
was indicted for that
he, on the 9th of December , with a certain pistol, loaded with gunpowder and a leaden bullet, feloniously and maliciously did shoot at
Thomas Lomath
, with intent to kill and murder him .
THREE OTHER COUNTS, stating his intention to be to maim, disable, or do him some grievous bodily harm.
MR. ALLEY conducted the prosecution.

Prisoner. I acknowledge having fired at him; it was in defence of the holy name I called out, which was "Rise green Loretto - her green flags," the mother of our blessed Saviour, the holy church of Rome; I called to her green flags to rise up, and so they will rise, and all the subjects of hell be crushed; it was in defence of her holy name that I fired - thank God, her green flags will rise up; she is the mother of our holy Saviour, and she is the holy church of Rome; she is the virgin rose, thanks be to her sweet holy name - she is our goddess in Rome; I would fire at his master in defence of that holy name.

THOMAS LOMATH. I am a Policeman . On Thursday last, about eleven o'clock in the morning, I was in Broadway, Westminster, and saw the prisoner about the middle of the road, making towards King's Head-court
, with a pistol in each hand, flourishing them over his head, and using some language that I did not understand; he then went towards the court - I followed him; he went to the front door on the left-hand side of the court, and tried to open it, but could not - he immediately turned round, came off the step of the door, and saw me very near him; I had not touched him, or said a word to him - he then looked me very hard in the face; I stared him hard in the face - at that time he had his hands down by his side, with the pistols in them; he cocked the large pistol, which was in his right hand - he did not make any effort to shoot at that moment, and I thought by that the pistol was not loaded; I then made a reach towards him- he then presented the pistol towards my breast, and it went off; I had gone towards him after it was presented- that turned the pistol on one side, and the shot did no mischief; he fired the pistol - I was within about four yards of him; he then turned himself round from me, and went across the court; I do not recollect his saying anything on firing - I went close after him, seized him by his neck, pushed him close against the wall, and pinued him to the wall; he put his hand over my neck, and knocked my hat off, and then, I suppose, he was trying to change the pistols, but I could not see behind me - he appeared to wish to change the large pistol from his right-hand, and get the other from his left; I then let go of his neck, and caught hold of both his arms - he then made another effort to change the pistols; no one came to my assistance - at last several persons came up, and both pistols were taken from him; I did not see the other examined.
Cross-examined by MR. CRESWELL. Q. You first saw him flourishing the pistols in the air, and using incoherent expressions? A. Yes.
COURT. Q. Had you seen or known him before? A. Not to my knowledge; I never had any conversation with him, or affronted him in any way.

GEORGE LEWIS
. I am a potato-salesman. I saw the prisoner flourishing two pistols in the air, and exclaiming something; I saw Lomath with him - I ran, and took the pistols, from him; one was loaded with powder and three slugs - he was flourishing the large one in his right hand, and the other in his left.
Cross-examined. Q. He was using incoherent language? A. Yes, something about green flags.

COURT. Q. Did you know him before? A. Yes, he has dealt at my shop for eight or nine months; I saw him very frequently, and conversed with him - be seemed to me as if he knew how to behave himself; he always conversed with the greatest propriety; be ordered what he wanted, and had it home regularly - I never noticed any thing incoherent in him till that morning, then there was a change in him - I thought it strange to see him flourishing pistols; I never saw him with a pistol before - I did not consider them loaded till I saw the large one discharged.

JOHN TAYLOR
. I live in York-street, Westminster, and am a pensioner from the 3rd regiment of Foot. I assisted in apprehending the prisoner, and took the smallpistol from him; I first saw him in Broadway, turning towards King's Head-court, flourishing the pistols, and saying what I could not understand - it was something in the manner he has to-day; he seemed outrageous.

THOMAS ASHTON
. I am a Policeman. I searched the prisoner's person, and found fourteen sovereigns, two half-sovereigns, and a duplicate, tied up in his shirt tail; he had got pockets.

Prisoner. You have sworn wrong; it was not in my shirt tail, it was tied about my side, with about 3l. worth of holy prints of the holy church of Rome, the mother of our Lord. - Witness. There was a 1d 1/2. in his breeches pocket - I saw no prints or papers; a small bag was given to me, containing a crucifix - I never saw him before.

FREDERICK GROSSMITH
. I am inspector of the Westminster division of the Police. I searched the prisoner's apartment, and found in a box a blunderbuss not loaded, a canister of powder for 1lb., a quantity of bullets and swan shot, a few gun flints, and some pistol flints - I also found a bundle of papers, not prints: there was nobody in the room - he has a daughter sixteen years old, but no wife.

JOHN BATHO. The prisoner lodged in my house, No. 7, Broadway, Westminster; the apartment searched belonged to him, he has one daughter - he had been in a very unsettled state of mind before this; I have known him about three months - I live in the house myself; about six weeks ago, he came down on a Monday morning when he usually pays his rent, he fell down on his knees three times in my shop, and talked incoherently, as he has done to day; I observed the same conduct two or three times since - he has not appeared to me at all in his right mind for the last six weeks; one night, about six weeks ago, I heard a quarrel up stairs between his daughter and himself, and repeated cries of murder from her - I went up and endeavoured to pacify him; she had offended him, but in what way I cannot say; she told me he had been beating her, and put my hand to her head to feel a blow he had inflicted - I had seen no provocation on her part towards him; this ill treatment occurred about twice, to my knowledge - but the day after this happened she left home and did not return; I consider his mind overpowered by Religion.

Prisoner's Defence. What I have to say is, I cried out"Rose green Loretto, her green flags rise up:" that is,"Blessed mother Loretto, mother of our church, and goddess above rise up" - I said nothing else till the man arrested me, and I fired at him in defence of her name; she is our goddess, and every body that does not believe in her cannot be saved - the law of God must not be broken, and if they do not believe in her, that will become their condemnation; it is useless for them to be ignorant and live in darkness - she is the light from Heaven that is bestowed that the world should not be so dark; all nations will worship her, it is the will of God, and the will of God must be done, and will be done - I fired in defence of that holy name; I would have fired at him, or any body, in defence of that holy name - I molested nobody; no heretic that does not believe on her, will ever see the light of Heaven - I leave it all to Almighty God; God knows the best.
The prisoner had interrupted the witnesses several times during the trial with the same sort of language, and whenever insanity was alluded to he always declared that he was "always in his senses."

MR. MCMURDO. I am surgeon of Newgate. I have examined the prisoner three or four times; I have seen him daily while he has been in the prison- I have no doubt at all of his being in a state of extreme insanity.
COURT. Q. This incoherent manner does not appear put on, but a real disordered state of intellect? A. It does- I always found him in the same state.

DR. MILLER. I accompanied Mr. McMurdo to see the prisoner last Saturday - I did not anticipate being called as a witness, but from what I saw of him that day, I conclude he is of unsound mind, and that is my opinion now; I have not the least doubt of his being insane.
THOMAS LOMATH. I heard the report of the pistol; it made a very loud report.
Prisoner. It was in the execution of my duty as a Christian to destroy that man, and the honour of my church, because he is rotten and blind - that holy name, there is no other God but her.
NOT GUILTY, being Insane .
Before Mr. Justice Littledale.

178.
HANNAH NICHOLAS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of Novermber , 4 Ibs. of pork, value 18d., and 12 ozs. of cheese, value 4d. , the goods of
Thomas House
.

THOMAS HOUSE. I am a cheesemonger , and live in Shoreditch
. On Monday, the 29th of November, at three o'clock, I saw the prisoner near my shop, with a basket in her hand- I asked her what she had taken from my stall, as I had received information; I took her by the arm - she said,"For God's sake take it, and say nothing at all about it;" I took the basket from her, and found a piece of pork and a piece of cheese; the officer came and took her - I know the cheese to be mine, by the cut and quality; I had it on a board outside the window - I had seen it about five minutes before; I believe the pork to be mine, but cannot swear to it - I lost a piece like it, which was safe about ten minutes before.

JAMES HENLEY
. On the 29th of November, I was in Shoreditch - the prosecutor gave the prisoner into my charge; this pork and cheese were in the basket - as I took her to the office she said, "Mind, when you took me I was drunk;" I made her no reply - she feigned to be in liquor.
(Cheese produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I know I paid for the cheese - I have four children, and hope you will be merciful: I am a poor widow .
GUILTY, of stealing the cheese only. Aged 52.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined One Month .
Before Mr. Justice Littledale.

179.
WILLIAM KITCHEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of November , 1 pair of trousers, value 5s. , the goods of
Peter Pige
.

THOMAS COMBS. I am shopman to
Peter Pige
, a pawnbroker , of Church-street, Bethnal-green
. On the 5th of November, about four o'clock in the afternoon, I was at the shop door, and saw the prisoner standing opposite a pair of trousers which hung outside the window, and looking at them; he walked a little way down the street when he saw me looking at him, and shortly after I saw him again in the same place - I turned away, lookedagain, and saw him going down the street; I missed the trousers, and followed him - he walked down the street, and when he turned he ran as hard as he could; I ran after him, calling Stop thief! - he endeavoured to throw the trousers over a wall; they fell on the pavement - I picked them up, and gave them to the officer; I saw him throw them down - I followed and took him in Anchor-street. Spitalfields, and collared him; I told him I wanted him to go with me - he said, "What have I done?" I said, "You have stolen a pair of trousers;" he said, "I have stolen no trousers" - he began wrestling with me, and threw me down in the mud; I kept hold of him - we were both down; I saw a Policeman and gave him in charge.

Prisoner. I wish to ask him where they hung. Witness. On an iron rail over the shop window - my head was turned when they were taken; I saw a young woman pass while he stood there, and he spoke to her -I lost sight of him twice; some boys told me which way you were gone - I went, and saw you walking as if nothing had happened; when I took you over two boys said you were not the man.

COURT. Q. Did you see the trousers go out of his hand? A. I did - I am confident he is the man; he had a stick in his hand, and wore a jacket - I am confident of his features; I did not take him a quarter of a mile off - he could walk there in three minutes.

WILLIAM BRADFORD
. I am a Policeman. On the 5th of Novermber Combs gave the prisoner into my charge, about four or five o'clock, with the trousers, which I have had ever since.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner. He says he apprehended me near four o'clock - I came out of the Jolly Weavers, in Weaver-street, at five minutes to five. Witness. It might be a quarter past four o'clock, when I first saw him: I took him about half-past - (looking at his deposition) it says five o'clock here, but I do not think they have taken me down right; I said the same as I say now.

Prisoner's Defence. I was coming out of Wheeler-street - it wanted five minutes to five o'clock when I went to have a glass of beer; when I came out he took hold of me, and said I stole a pair of trousers - I was not within a quarter of a mile of the pawnborker's.

GUILTY . Aged 28. -
Confined Six Months .
Before Mr. Baron Vaughan.

180.
WILLIAM JAMIESON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of December , 1 portmantaeu, value 12s. , the goods of
Adam Murgatroyd
.

ADAM MURGATROYD
. I am a trunk-maker , and live at Knightsbridge
. On the 8th of December, about one o'clock, I missed a portmanteau from my shop.

ROBERT DRIVER
. I live opposite to the prosecutor's. On the 8th of December I saw the prisoner reach over into the shop, take a portmanteau, and run across the road with it - I went, and informed the prosecutor.
Prisoner. Q. Can you positively swear I am the person? A. Yes.

JOHN HILLMAN
. I live with Driver. He told me to go after the prisoner - I followed, and found him in Wilton-crescent; I brought him back with the portmantean.

NATHANIEL BRITTAN
. I was coming up Knights-bridge, and met the prosecutor holding the prisoner - he gave him in charge for stealing a portmanteau, which he had left in the shop; I searched, but found nothing on him - he met a man on the road, who laughed at him: he said that man might be in the same situation as himself, and if he did steal it, nobody knew his circumstances better than himself.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Confined Six Months .
Before Mr. Justice Littledale.

181.
WILLIAM HODGKINSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of December , I sovereign, 2 half-crowns, and 1 sixpence, the goods of
Joseph Barton
, from his person .

JOSEPH BARTON
. I am a bricklayer , and live in Clerkenwell-close. On Sunday morning, the 5th of December, I was going home at very near five o'clock, and met the prisoner in Lincoln's Inn-fields - I was intoxicated- I went into the Coach and Horses, Holborn
, with him; it is near Red Lion-street - we had a pint of half ale and half porter; I had a sovereign, two half-crowns. and a shilling in my left-hand waistcoat pocket - I took it all out of my pocket, paid for the beer with a shilling, and received 6d. in change, which I put with the other money -I fell asleep, and awoke about half-past five o'clock; I felt my pocket, and the money was all gone - a Policeman had him in custody at that time, and I saw my money in the Policeman's hands; I did not know the prisoner before - he was sitting by my side when I fell asleep.
Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. And there he was when you awoke? A. Yes; he was on my left-hand side - he had not gone away; I believe he was sober - I had my recollection about me; I could walk.

Q. Were you drunk enough for any body to see you were not sober? A. Yes: he offered to assist me, and did so to the Coach and Horses - I had no rum there; I believe the half-and - half came to 3d. - I do not know what a quartern of rum comes to; I believe I was laying down in Lincoln's Inn-fields, and the prisoner lifted me up - he could have robbed me there; my money was found in his left hand - he said he was going to deposit it with the landlord to take care of for me.

DAVID GRIFFITHS
. I am a saddler, and live in Oxford-street. I was at the Coach and Horses on the 5th of December - I went in at twenty minutes past five o'clock, and in a few minutes Barton and the prisoner came in; I saw them drinking together - Barton was very much intoxicated; he fell asleep about ten minutes after, calling for a pint of half-and - half, and I saw the prisoner put his left hand into Barton's left-hand waistcoat pocket - he took out some money; I could not see what - I went out for an officer, and brought Fisher in with me; I told him the prosecutor had just been robbed - he asked where the man was who had robbed him; I pointed to the prisoner, and said I believed he had the money then in his left hand - the Policeman found in his left hand a sovereign, two half-crowns, and a sixpence; this was as near half-past five o'clock as possible.

Cross-examined. Q. How long were you absent looking for the Policeman? A. About a minute; the prisoner said he took it with the whole and sole intention of delivering it into the landlord's hands; he said that when it was found in his hand - he said nothing when he took it out, but I said, "You have just robbed that man," and he made no answer - he had time to put the money into his pocket while I was away; he could not have escaped conveniently, because I scarcely got outside before I met a Policeman; there might be seven or eight people in the house - the prosecutor sat next the fire-place, the prisoner next, and I next to him; others were in a better situation for seeing it than me, if they had looked, but nobody saw it; I can swear no rum was called for.

JAMES FISHER
. I am a Policeman. I went with Griffiths into the Coach and Horses, at half-past five o'clock in the morning, and in the prisoner's left hand I found a sovereign, two half-crowns, and a sixpence; I found a sixpence and 3 1/2d. on him besides - when I took the money from his hand he said nothing about giving it up to me.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you not hear him say he intended to give it to the landlord to take care of? A. I did not - if it was said it must be before I came in; he made no resistance - I took him to the watch-house.
Prisoner's Defence. The prosecutor says I was on his left hand - I was on his right.
NOT GUILTY .
Second London Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

182.
PETER GRIEVES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of December , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
Henry Sweet
, from his person .

HENRY SWEET. I am apprentice d to Mr. Webster, a baker, of Coleman-street. On the 9th of December, about half-past six o'clock in the evening. I was opposite St. Bride's church, Fleet-street
; I did not perceive any thing done, but a young man informed me my handkerchief was gone - I felt in my pocket, and missed it; it was silk, and worth 3s. or 4s. - I had had it in my hand not five minutes before; I saw it again in about three minutes, and knew it to be mine - the young man who gave the information laid hold of the prisoner with me.
Prisoner. Q. What pocket was your handkerchief in? A. The left-hand.

THOMAS TOOLE
. I am a journeyman shoemaker, and live at No. 22, Goswell-street. On the 9th of December I was in Fleet-street, and saw the prisoner with a companion, trying two or three person's pockets who stood at a picture-shop window - Sweet was looking at that window; it is exactly opposite St. Bride's church - I saw the prisoner put his hand into Sweet's pocket, take the handkerchief out, and put it into the flap of his trousers; he and his companion both walked away together - (I should know his companion, he was taken and discharged); I immediately told Sweet to feel in his pocket, and he missed his handkerchief; he and I followed the prisoner - I collared him four or five doors from the print-shop, and charged him with it; he denied it, and said he had no handkerchief- I put my hand into the flap of his breeches, and took it from there; Sweet claimed it - I am positive it was the handkerchief I had seen him take from Sweet: I took him and his companion to the watch-house-they were both together; I gave the handkerchief to the officer.

Prisoner. Q. You say you saw me pick the man's pocket - of course you must know which pocket I took it out of? A. I think it was from the left-hand pocket, but cannot be certain; he was close to the pockets - I did not say at the watch-house that I saw the other take it and give it to you.

Q. How was it you did not take me instantly? A. I wanted to tell Sweet first; you walked away while I was telling him - I took you within two or three doors of Fleet-market, four or five doors or more from the picture-shop.

WILLIAM BETTERTON
. I am an officer of the Mansion-house. I received the prisoner in charge with the handkerchief, which I have kept ever since.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. On the Saturday before this took place, I had only come from the country, where I had been working at the cotton business a number of years; on the night I was taken I was merely stopping at the window, like another man, and on moving I felt something under my feet; I stooped to see what it was, and it was this handkerchief - I picked it up, and put it into my pocket, but as to stealing it I did not, and had not such a thought in my head.

GUILTY . Aged 26. -
Transported for Life .

183.
JOHN FARRELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of November , I handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
William Dilnot Wildish
, from his person .

WILLIAM DILNOT WILDISH. I live in Waterloo-place, Pall-mall, and am steward to the Union Literary Club . -On the 9th of November I had been out about three hours, and had my handkerchief safe when I left home - it was silk, and worth 3s,; I used it frequently, and can say it was safe half an hour before it was missed, which was about one o'clock, when I was near St. Bride's church, in Fleet-street
; there was a crowd passing - a great many persons were walking together, on the footpath: I felt my handkerchief taken, and turned round - I saw the prisoner and another person with him; I concluded it must be one of them - I laid hold of the prisoner, in cousequence of seeing the end of the handkerchief hanging out of his pocket; I asked him what he wanted with my handkerchief - he said he knew nothing of it: his companion walked on - I took my handkerchief from his pocket; there was an officer on the spot, and I gave it to him - the prisoner said at the watch-house that he hoped I should not appear against him, for if I did he should be sent out of the country.

GEORGE FREDERICK POOLE
. I am inspector of St. Bride's watch. I was close to the prisoner when the prosecutor put his hand into his pocket, and took the handkerchief out - I saw nobody in his company: I took him into custody, and Wildish claimed the handkerchief.
JURY. Q. Did you see the prisoner take the handkerchief from the prosecutor? A. No. I saw the prosecutor take it out of the prisoner's pocket.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I know nothing about the handkerchief; I do not know how it came there.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Life .
NEW COURT. TUESDAY, DECEMBER 14.
Third, Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

184.
MARY MOORE
was indicted for
stealing, onthe 30th of November , 1 gown, value 4s. , the goods of
John Bowles
.

MARTHA BOWLES
. I am the wife of John Bowles - we keep a clothes-shop . About half-past four o'clock, on the 30th of November, I locked the shop door, went down into the kitchen, and in five minutes I heard the shop door bell ring; I went up in a few minutes, and saw the prisoner coming out of the shop door, which was then open - I asked if she had been into the shop; she said No - I said I was sure I had locked the shop door, and she must have broken it open; she said she wanted some linen rags, and they must be very clean, as they were for a particular purpose - I said I had none, and while I was speaking to her, I saw the gown under her feet; she was going, but I said I would not let her go yet, and pushed her back into the shop; I saw the gown under her feet - it had been on a shelf in the window when I went down stairs; I had to unlock the shop door before I could lock it again, but how she opened it I cannot say - some force must have been used.

Prisoner. You know very well, I only just touched the door, and the bell rang, Witness. Yes, the bell rang with the door being opened; she was going from the passage - she had one foot in the street, and one on the threshold; I made her stop - I took her back; I said I had met with a very heavy loss at my door, and for her impudence I would follow her as far as the law would allow; I said I had lost some silver spoons - she swore a great many oaths; I said I would make her pay for all -I called a man out of the kitchen, who went for a Policeman; she did not attempt to go away - I was on one side of the counter, and she on the other; I cannot say who was nearest the window; she was not three yards from the gown when I took it up - the whole place is not three yards.
COURT. Q. Are you sure you saw the gown upon her arm before you brought her into the shop? A. I saw a piece of it under her arm.

Prisoner. Q. If you saw it why did you say you would have me searched? A. I did not say so at the shop - I said at the watch-house, "I dare say she may have the duplicate of the other things I have lost."

HENRY JACKSON
. I came up from the kitchen, and saw Mrs. Bowles pushing the prisoner into the shop - I saw the gown under the prisoner's feet at the side of the counter.
Prisoner. You never saw the gown till you brought the officer. Witness. Yes, I did, under your feet, and there in the mark of your feet on it now.

ALEXANDER MCCULLICK
. I took the prisoner on the 30th of November - I found an old cap on her.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I certainly went into the shop to ask for white linen rags; I turned the handle of the door, and the bell rang - I waited a moment, and Mrs. Bowles came up and asked what I wanted; she said she had none- I was turning out at the door, when she said, "Come back, woman - I was robbed a fortnight ago, and perhaps you are the same party;" I staid very quietly while the man was gone for the officer, and she went round into the parlour - she stooped, and picked up the gown the length of the counter from me; she said, "Here is a gown which was in the window, and which you must have had."

GUILTY . Aged 55. -
Confined Two Years .

185.
ANN MURRELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of November , 4 half-crowns, the monies of
William Jacks
, from his person .

WILLIAM JACKS. I live in Mary-street, Stepney. On the 14th of November I was returning home through Old-street-road
- the prisoner accosted me, and endeavoured in prevail on me to go down a dark turning in the street; I objected - she then commenced taking liberties with me, which I did not think proper to encourage; she threw her arms round my waist - I told her to desist, as I wanted to go home; she let go and walked away from me for two or three minutes; I then put my hand into my waistcoat pocket, which, two or three minutes before had contained four half-crowns and some halfpence, and it was gone - I turned back and ran after her; I came up with her in company with another woman, about a hundred yards from where I had seen her before; I took hold of them both, and gave them both into custody - I had been drinking, but was quite sensible of what was passing; I had been to my club, in John-street, and then to the Lord Nelson, and about twenty minutes before I left the Lord Nelson I saw the four half-crowns safe in my waistcoat pocket, with some half-pence; I told the officer I had been robbed of four or five half-crowns - I saw four half-crowns produced from the prisoner's person.

JAMES THOMSON
. I took the prisoner - I found on her four half-crowns, some halfpence, and one farthing; the prosecutor seemed a little fresh, but perfectly sensible - before I searched the prisoner she said she had nothing at all but two or three halfpence; when I had searched her and found the half-crowns, she said."I did not think proper to tell you what I had;" she said the money was her own, and some gentleman, a friend of hers, had given it her - she said in Pitfield-street that she had seen the prosecutor, but did not take any thing from him.

JOHN COOK
. I am landlord of the Lord Nelson. I changed a sovereign for the prosecutor, about six o'clock that evening - he owed me 3s. 3d., and he spent 8d.; I gave him six half-crowns, one shilling, and one penny-piece - he came again about five minutes past eight, but had nothing at that time; his master had given them a supper that night.

WILLIAM JOHN SMITH
. I am a member of a club which is held at the Angel, in John-street; I saw the prosecutor there between six and seven o'clock that night, and he paid me half a crown.

HENRY JONES
. I live in Phillips-street. St. George's. Between seven and eight o'clock that night the prisoner changed a half-crown at my bar, and received 2s. 2d.

Prisoner's Defence. I went as far as Charing-cross, and met a gentlemen I have not seen for several years, and he gave me that trifle of silver - I returned and met a female; I was in conversation with her, and this gentleman came up very tipsy; he ran against us, and turned round to say some bad word - he then said, "You are the person who robbed me" - I said, "Go along;" he called the officer; they found the four half-crowns which the gentleman had given me - the prosecutor said he had lost five half-crowns, and at Worship-street he said it was only four half-crowns, when be found what I had in my pocket.

WILLIAM JACKS
. I said four or five to the best of my recollection.

GUILTY . Aged 33. -
Transported for Seven Years .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

186.
JOHN MURPHY
and
HENRY MURPHY
were indicted for
stealing on the 8th of November , I hat, value 18s. , the goods of
Patrick Hawkins
.

MARY HAWKINS
. I am the wife of Patrick Hawkins. The two prisoner's lodged in the same house as us - on the 8th of November I put this hat into my box: Henry was sitting by at the time, but John never came into my room: I afterwards missed the bat - this is it, but this is not the box.

GEORGE EASTMAN
. I live at a pawnbroker's in Holborn. This hat was pawned with me on the 8th of November, by the two prisoners together, but I received it of the father.
MARY HAWKINS. This is the hat - it is not mine, but was in my care; the prisoners had no right in my room, but that morning Henry came in and sat by the fire.

JOHN MURPHY
-
GUILTY . Aged 45.
Confined One Month .

HENRY MURPHY
-
NOT GUILTY .

187.
ALFRED BOUCHER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of November , 2 pairs of stockings, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
William Champion
.

WILLIAM CLAPP. I live with my father, in Kingsland-road
. On the evening of the 30th of November I was at my father's door, and saw the prisoner; he passed and looked very hard at me - I watched him, and saw him cross to Mr. Champion's door; he unpinned these stockings, which were hanging at the door - I called my father's apprentice, who ran after him; I saw the prisoner fold up the stockings and put them under his coat.

JOHN WARLEY
. I am the officer. My wife told me the prosecutor had been robbed of some stockings - the prisoner had then got into his own house; one of the boys knocked at the door, and when I got in I found these stockings under the bed, and no one but the prisoner was in the room.

HENRY ROWLAND
. I went after the prisoner - he looked at me, gave a sudden turn, and went through a public-house.
WILLIAM CHAMPION. I am the owner of the shop . These are my stockings - I missed two like them, but it is impossible to swear to a stocking.
Prisoner's Defence. They took one boy first, and then came and took me.

GUILTY . Aged 13. -
Transported for Seven Years .

188.
ELIZABETH LANDIGAN. alias HURLEY
, was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of November , I coat, value 10s., and I cloak, value 6s. , the goods of
Joseph Davis
.

MARY DAVIS
. I am the wife of Joseph Davis; we live in Chapel-street, Soho
. On Friday, the 5th of November. I left my apartment to go in the kitchen, leaving my little girl there - she left to go to school, and left the door locked; when I returned the articles stated were gone - the officer brought them the next morning.

RICHARD JAMES JEFFERY
. I am apprentice to a pawnbroker, in Drury-lane - the prisoner brought these things on the 5th of November, between three and half-past three o'clock - she said she brought them from a person named Morgan, a person we knew, and with whom the prisoner had lived - I had received previous information, and gave her in charge.

MARY DAVIS. These are my property - the person who took them might have gone in at the street door, and unlocked my door, which is up two pair of stairs; when I returned from the kitchen the drawers were opened, and I missed these articles.

GUILTY . Aged 11. -
Transported for Seven Years .
There were two other indictments against the prisoner.

189.
THOMAS LANGHORN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of November , I pelisse, value 30s. , the goods of
Eleanor Cavanagh
.

ELEANOR CAVANAGH. I am single - the prisoner lived in the same house with me and his mother; he has no father. On the 10th of November, I put my pelisse in the drawer, and on the 14th I missed it - I waited till the 27th, and then asked the prisoner about it; he would not own to it - I went for the officer, and saw the duplicate found on him.

SAMUEL FLETCHER
. I have a silk pelisse which I took in on the 13th of November, of a young man, but I cannot say whether it was the prisoner - I gave him this duplicate.

FRANCIS BROWN
. I am the officer. I was sent for and took the prisoner; I found four duplicates on him - one is for this pelisse.
Prisoner's Defence. I picked up the duplicate, and they found it on me.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Whipped and Discharged.

190.
JAMES KIRBY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of November , 1 handkerchief, value 3s. , the goods of
William John Hewitson
.

GEORGE ARNOLD
. I am apprentice to
William John Hewitson
- he keeps a shop in Kingsland-road
. On the 25th of November I saw the prisoner take down a handkerchief which was pinned to a gown inside the shop; he was rolling it up - I ran and collared him; I had seen him looking very hard through the window before he took it- this is the handkerchief.

Prisoner's Defence. I worked three years and a half for Mr. Osborne - he has not had work for me this mouth - I was looking for work, and saw this handkerchief at the door - I looked at it with an intention of buying it; it came down - I took it up, and was going to put it in the rack when the man took me.

GEORGE SMITH
. I am the officer - I took the prisoner, and found only 2 1/2d. on him.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY Aged 16. -
Recommended to Mercy ,
Fined 1s., and delivered to his employer .

191.
EDWARD KEMP
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of November , 1 coat, value 2l., and I handkerchief, value 6d. , the goods of
John Edds
.
MR. CHURCHILL conducted the prosecution.

JOHN EDDS
. I am a watchman in the service of the New River Company . I was on duty at half-past four o'clock in the morning, on the 26th of November; I took off my great-coat and laid it on the vice-bench, in the smith's shop, while I went into the engine-house - I was about an hour in the engine-house; when I returned my coat was gone - the prisoner worked there, and I hadsome suspicion, and went in the afternoon to look for him- I found him coming out of Smith field, and gave charge of him; on his person was found this handkerchief, which had been in my coat pocket, and this knife which had been by the side of it.

HENRY WOODROFFE
. I am an officer - I took the prisoner, and found this knife and handkerchief on him- he had been ten months in that situation; the coat has not been found.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 29. -
Transported for Seven Years .

192.
GEORGE KING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of December , 1 cheese, value 10s. , the goods of
William Dicken
.

JOHN LONDON
. I met the prisoner on the 2nd of December, carrying this cheese; I asked where he got it - he said a man gave it to him to carry to the other side of Brentford-bridge; he had no settled place to take it to, but the man was to meet him.
WILLIAM DICKEN. I keep a cheesemonger's-shop . The officer brought this cheese, which I knew to be mine - it had been one foot within my door; I had not missed it.
Prisoner's Defence. I was going up the street; a man asked me if I would earn 6d. - I took the cheese, and the man followed me as far as the Half-acre, when the officer stopped me.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Confined Three Months .

193.
SAMUEL HARGRAVE
was indicted for
stealing on the 2nd of December , 1 pair of shoes, value 3s. , the goods of
John Dawson
.

FRANCES DAWSON
. I am the wife of
John Dawson
- we live in Monmouth-street
. On the 2nd of December I saw the prisoner, and watched him for some time; he was then alone; I then saw him with another bigger boy - he passed our door, but I did not see him take the shoes; he passed again, and I saw he had them under his arm; I ran, and cried Stop thief! he threw down the shoes, and the officer took them up; they are my husband's property.

WILLIAM ARNEY
. I saw the prisoner running, and the prosecutor following him; I took the shoes up.
Prisoner's Defence. The other boy gave them to me.

GUILTY . Aged 9. -
Transported for Seven Years .

194.
JOHN HATCH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of December , 1 purse, value 1s., 4 sovereigns, and 1 half-sovereign, the monies of
Samuel Hodges
, from his person .

SAMUEL HODGES. I am a veterinary surgeon , and reside at the Veterinary-college, Camden-town. At two o'clock in the morning of the 5th of December I was returning home from Drury-lane theatre; I was sober, and had got nearly as far as Little Turnstile
, when the prisoner met me, and without any provocation he struck me in the breast, and knocked me down; as I was attempting to rise he drew the sheath from a sword-stick which I had - he put it to his knee, and broke it, threw one part of it away, and was coming at me again with the other part, with an intent of striking me - I gave up the sword-stick to a person who was near, closed with the prisoner, and we both fell, I was undermost - I then felt the prisoner at my right-hand side, attempting to take my watch, and trying to break the guard; the Policeman came up at that instant - I lost four sovereigns and a half from my trousers pocket, and my trousers were very much torn on the left side, where my purse had been; I have no doubt whatever but that he took my money - I have never seen it since: it was in a green purse altogether; the Policeman took him into custody; the purse and all were taken.

Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. How many person were about at the time? A. I did not see any person except the one to whom I gave the sword-stick - I believe when I got up there were two or three persons; none of them are here - in two or three minutes, I suppose, there were a dozen, but no one was near me till the Policeman came up; my friend is not here - the Policeman took the sword-stick from the man I gave it to: I believe he was a bricklayer - I believe one of the Policemen saw the beginning of the transaction; I was sober - I suppose the theatre closed about a quarter-past twelve o'clock; I then went to an oyster-shop, but had nothing to drink there - I do not know the name of the street; I am a stranger in town - I suppose I staid there an hour; I have the watch-guard on now which he was trying to break - the prisoner appeared to be drunk when he was taken; I did not make an observation about his being drunk before he struck me - no one was with him; I have not seen the purse since; I did not see any one near him at the time - there were plenty there in two or three minutes; I charged him with attempting to take my watch and purse before I got to the watch-house; I had seen my purse safe about two minutes before, as I had met a Policeman, and asked him to direct me to Somer's-town, and he did - I took my purse out to give him some silver, but I had none; I then put it in again safe.

JOHN WESTCOMBE
. I am a Police-constable, and was on duty near Turnstile. I heard the cry of Police! went to the spot, and found Mr. Hodges rising from the ground- I saw the prisoner draw the sheath from his stick; he broke it, threw one piece away, and approached him with the other piece - they fell, and I came up and took the prisoner, while he lay on Mr. Hodges; I took charge of him- the prosecutor did not say the attempt at that moment: I took the prisoner to the watch-house, but found no money; a great many people had collected, and I gave him to my brother officer - in going along Great Queen-street; the prosecutor said he had robbed him of his purse.

Cross-examined. Q. Then he said nothing about his attempting to rob him at the time? A. He said he was going to take his watch away - when I came up to the place there were a dozen or near two dozen of common girls; there were three or four round at the time I came up - there were several round; I did not see the prisoner searched - I examined the place where the scuffle occurred after the prosecutor said he had lost his purse; there were some girls about the place - I saw the prosecutor rising from the ground, and the prisoner take the sword-sheath; the prisoner had an opportunity of handing away the purse if he had taken it - there were several persons round who attempted to hustle me off; I do not cousider that the prisoner was any more drunk than I am at this present time;he pretended to he drunk - several people followed us, and a great many staid.

JOHN CARLISLE
. I am a Policeman. I met the prosecutor at Turnstile, and he asked me the way to Somers' - town- I went and showed him part of the way; this was about two o'clock in the morning - he pulled out his purse, and said, "I have no silver, or I would give you something;" I said it was not required; I bade him good night, and soon after I heard Police! called - I went up, and took the prisoner from my brother officer - I took him to the watch-house, and searched him, but could find nothing but a few half-pence and some silver; there was a mob when I came up.

Cross-examined. Q. Were any other persons near enough to take the purse from him? A. Yes, there was, from the prisoner or the prosecutor - they touched them: I believe the prisoner was let out afterwards, but I cannot say.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going along Holborn, near Little Turnstile - the prosecutor said something to me about my being tipsy; I cannot recollect the words he said, but I turned round, and said if I was, it was not at his expence - he then gave me a slap on the face; I knocked him down, and in rising I saw he was drawing a sword-stick; I grasped at it, and broke it - he closed, and we fell.
Witnesses for the Defence.

JOHN MCGRATH
. I am a Policeman. I was present when the prisoner was taken; I was informed he was bailed out on the Sunday, but I was not there - there was no charge made against him that night; it was by my orders that the prisoner and the prosecutor were taken to the watch-house, for being fighting in the street - they were both detained; this young gentleman was going about with a sword in his hand - he came to me, and said."Policeman, shake hands, I like the Police force, and the system too;" I then heard, Police! called, and ran up to the place - it was by my orders the prisoner and he were sent to the watch-house; the prosecutor never charged him with attempting to rob him till an hour and a half after they were in the watch-house; I heard they were let out on bail - the prosecutor was let out the same morning.

COURT. Q. Were you at Turnstile at the time? A. Not at the first attack; I was a reserved man at the station-house, but was sent out patroling - it was between Turnstile and Holborn that I saw the parties; it was by my orders both of them were taken - there was a common woman of the town there; this young gentleman said,"This man knocked me down, and we had a fight;" I did not come up till the mob had gathered - I am not an inspector or superior officer, I am only a private Policeman; these others are my equals - they had seen more of the transaction; they had not got hold of the prisoner at the time I came up - there is another officer coming here; we considered that the best way was to take them to the station.

JOHN CARLISLE
re-examined. McGrath and I both ran together when we heard Police! called, I took the prisoner from Westcombe - I did not see the prisoner strike the prosecutor, or knock him down; nobody ordered them to go to the station, that I know of.

COURT to JOHN WESTCOMBE. Q. You took the prisoner, and gave him to Carlisle? A. Yes - I did not hear McGrath give any charge; he came up after I had hold of the prisoner - he did not order us to take them to the station; he gave no direction that I heard - he came up after I had the prisoner in custody; I did not go to the watch-house myself.

COURT to
JOHN CARLISLE
. Q. Why was the prosecutor put into the watch-house? A. I took him there, and another officer, not here, took the prisoner; I do not know who the officer was - I did not know at that time that the prosecutor had lost any money - he then stated he was robbed, and I searched the prisoner; I took him, not knowing exactly what the charge was, but he charged him with it at the watch-house.
COURT to JOHN WESTCOMBE. Q. You saw the transaction in the manner you have related? A. Yes, my Lord; the prosecutor did not mention about his watch till he was at the station-house.
MR. CHURCHILL. Q. But you had him at the station-house before that? A. Yes.

MR. CHURCHILL to
JOHN CARLISLE
. Q. Do you know of their being in custody the whole night? A. The prosecutor was let out in about an hour and a half afterwards- I appeared at Bow-street against the prisoner; he was sent from our station house, but I do not know by whom.
JOHN WESTCOMBE. The prisoner came to me.

WILLIAM BIDMEAD
. I am a letter-press printer, in the employ of Vizetelly and Branston. I bailed the prisoner, and he remained at my house till six or seven o'clock on the Sunday evening; on the Monday morning, at half-past nine, I had occasion to go out - on my return he was waiting at my house, and said to me, "Come, young fellow, or we shall be too late," and we went to the Police-office; I have known him two years - he has been an honest young man.

COURT. Q. Did he keep good hours? A. Yes; when I have known him he always was at work at his regular time; I had seen him up to nine o'clock on that Saturday evening, when we were paid, and then we parted - I know where he went to; I did not go to Turnstile - I was in bed about twelve o'clock; the amount of the bail I gave was 20l. - that was before the inspector, who is not here; the inspector read the charge over to me, and it was for disorderly conduct in the street, and a street fight or row, I will not be positive which; he was not charged with felony at the time of bail.

SAMUEL HODGES re-examined. Q. When was the first time you said you had been robbed of your purse? A. In five or ten minutes - the moment I missed it; I stated it when I got to the watch-house, and the prisoner was searched immediately - the inspector put me in a little room by the side, came and spoke to me, and then let me out on bail; I told the inspector I had been robbed, and he ordered the prisoner to be searched - I signed my hand to a paper.
COURT to JOHN WESTCOMBE. Q. What is the name of the inspector? A. Wovington, inspector of F. division, at the Covent-garden station.

JOHN LOVIT
. I am a printer, and have been foreman to Vizitelly and Branston for two years. The prisoner worked for them, and had a good character; I saw him on the Monday when he was going to the office, and begged of him to return as early as possible - he said,"I dare say I shall be fined 5s. for being drunk, and I shall return directly after dinner."

COURT. Q. When did you part with him on the Saturday? A. At nine o'clock when I paid him; his habits at the printing-office are very regular - I cannot say how he is at home; I understood he had to go to Turnstile for a pair of shoes, which were to be left at a public-house - he lives in Poppin's-court, Fleet-street.

SAMUEL HODGES re-examined. I met him coming down Holborn, as I was going up towards Somers'-town - I was perfectly sober; there is no pretence for saying I spoke to the prisoner - I never spoke a word to him; he came and struck me.

- Pocock. I am a Policeman. I was not present at the time of the disturbance - I saw the prosecutor after the row; he gave no account of it at all - he did not say he was robbed till he got to the watch-house; I was close to him, and did not hear it - I took the prisoner; they were both confined - the charge against the prosecutor was for being drunk and disorderly; myself and Carlisle made the charge.
JOHN CARLISLE. I deny it - I did not.

- Pocock. I met this gentleman and another, a quarter of an hour before I heard Police! called; he pulled out his purse and offered Carlisle something to drink, but he had no silver - he then passed on towards Great Turnstile, and we heard Police! called, we ran back, and I and McGrath got up a minute and a half before Carlisle did.

SAMUEL HODGES re-examined. I have no recollection of seeing Pocock at all - I saw Carlisle, and asked him the road, and took out my purse; I put it safe back, and buttoned the pocket up - I was not drunk; I had been sitting five hours in the theatre, and then went to the oyster-shop, but I did not drink any thing, upon my oath.
NOT GUILTY .

195.
MARY HORNETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of November , 1 cloak, value 16s., the goods of
Richard Hall
and another .

THOMAS WOOLCOTT. I am in the service of Richard Hall and another - they are linen-draper s. The prisoner came to their shop on the 10th of November, and had a cloak on her arm, which I suspected she had stolen from the door; I looked, and missed one - she then put it on a stool; I served her with what she wanted, and she took the cloak and went out - I followed her six or seven yards from the door; I then examined the cloak, and found it was my employer's - I asked her how she got it; she said a woman gave it her to carry - I had never seen her before; this is the cloak.

Prisoner's Defence. I went to the prosecutor's shop, which is not five minutes walk from my lodging, to get some silk and some calico to finish my work - I came out and was crossing the road, when I recollected I wanted some black silk; I went back to the shop, and before I got to the window a woman asked me to carry the cloak to No. 12, Eyre-street-hill; I was going that way in a minute; I went into the shop, bought the silk, took up the cloak, and was coming out, not knowing it to be stolen- is it likely I should have gone and stolen the cloak in a public street, then go in, lay it down before the eyes of the shopman, take it up, and come out again with it?

THOMAS WOOLCOTT
. When I took her she said she hoped I would let her go. and it would be a warning to her in future.
Prisoner. I might say so at the time.

GUILTY . Aged 31. -
Transported for Seven Years .

196.
ISAAC HEATH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of November , 2 spoke-shaves, value 1s. 6d., and 1 plane, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
William King
.

WILLIAM KING. I am a coach-maker , and live in Woburn-buildings, near Russell-square
. The prisoner worked for me till November - I missed some tools before I parted with him.

FRANCIS PARKER
. I am a pawnbroker. I have two spoke-shaves pawned by the prisoner.

JOHN SPENCER
. I have a plane. pawned on the 22nd of September; I do not know by whom, but I gave the person this duplicate.

JOSEPH EDWARD PETTIT
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, and found on him thirteen duplicates, three of which relate to the property.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I went to work for another man for two or three weeks - I asked the prosocutor to lend me a spoke-shave; he said I might take two if I wanted them; I then worked for the prosecutor again, and asked him to lend me a saw and a plane - he said I might have them if I would bring the saw back directly, which I did- I then met with an accident, and broke a truss which I wore; I was forced to part with every thing I had to get another.

WILLIAM KING
. I had lent him a spoke-shave and a frame-saw, which he brought back again - I have known him for years, and never knew any thing against him before.

GUILTY . Aged 54 -
Confined Fourteen Days .

197.
DOROTHY FUDGE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of October , 1 handkerchief, value 6d.; 1 printed book, value 10s., and 2 stockings, value 6d. , the goods of
William Cookney
.

ELIZABETH COOKNEY
. I am the wife of William Cookney - we live in High-street, Shadwell
. The prisoner was our weekly servant ; I missed some articles on the 12th of October.

THOMAS SIZERS
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a pair of stockings, a handkerchief, and a book, pawned at different times; I know the book was pawned by the prisoner.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. The book belonged to her son, who is gone to sea.
ELIZABETH COOKNEY. Yes, but it was under my care.

GUILTY , Aged 30. -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

198.
MARY ELLIOTT, alias RILEY
, was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of November , 8 yards of woollen cloth, value 6l.; I gold ring, value 10s.; 2 yards of linen cloth, value 1s.; I napkin, value 2d., and I knife-handle, value 2d., the goods of
John Wills
, her master .

JOHN WILLS
. I am a master tailor , and live in St. James'-place
. The prisoner came into my service on the 18th of March last - she had not left me; I missed different articles, but up to last Sunday fortnight I had notsuspected her; the officer then called, and told me something.

BENJAMIN TIMBRELL
. I received information from
Sarah Grange
, that she had some cloth belonging to the prosecutor - I went and got it, and then went to the prosecutor; I found this table-cloth, this piece of linen, and this handle of a knife in the prisoner's pocket.

SARAH GRANGE
. I go out charing, and go by the prosecutor's regular every morning to fetch spring water; the prisoner called me and asked me if I would go on an errand for her; I said yes - she asked me to pawn this cloth; I took it to Mr. Williams', where I had pawned a gown, and he would not take it because it was not made up - the prisoner said I must take it. as she had no where to put it: I heard in the evening that it was wrong, and told all about the matter.

DANIEL RIERDON
. I am a serjeant of Police. I received some information on Sunday fortnight; I went to a woman named Britton, and found these articles, which I produce; I said I should take Britton - she said she could state who she had them of, and named the prisoner; I went to the prisoner the next morning and asked her - she said she never took any thing but what she had seen yesterday; I showed her some duplicates for pieces of cloth, two pledged in one day, and told her I found the duplicates at Britton's- she then said, "I did take them through distress;" I asked her about a ring, which she said she had taken, and I should find the duplicate.

ELIZA BRITTON
. I received a piece of cloth from the prisoner, to make a child a frock, but it was not enough, and my husband pawned it for her.

THOMAS COX
. I have a piece of cloth and a waistcoat-piece, pawned by a man in the name of
John Britton
.

EBENEZER HEMBRY
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a remnant of cloth, pawned by a man in the name of
John Britton
.

JAMES WALLIS
. I have a remnant of cloth and a ring pawn by Grange.

SARAH GRANGE
. The prisoner gave them to me to pawn, and I gave her the money.
DANIEL RIERDON. This is all that has been found, a great deal is lost.
The prisoner pleaded distress.

GUILTY . Aged 35. -
Transported for Seven Years .

199.
ROBERT COLLINS
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 29th of November , 1 cheese, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Zephaniah Simpson
, well knowing it to be stolen ; against the Statute.

LAWRENCE MAYER
. I am a coal-whipper. On the 29th of November, I saw the prisoner and another boy opposite Mr. Simpson's window; the other took the cheese, and the prisoner was close to him - I ran and took the prisoner; he had the cheese then, and let it fall.
NOT GUILTY .

200.
WILLIAM COLLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of November, 1 bundle of bristles, value 6s. , the goods of
William Poke
.

PETER HUNTER
. I live in Fisher-street, Red Lion-square
, opposite Mr. Poke's shop; he is a shoemaker's grinder - I went into his shop on the 18th of November, and saw the prisoner there with his face towards the window; he turned to go out - I said, "Young man, what have you got?" he made no answer - I attempted to follow him, but could not go fast enough; I called Stop thief! and he was stopped.

TIMOTHY BRITTON
. I am a Police-constable, I heard the alarm, and saw the prisoner run, a postman stopped him; I went up and took these bristles from his hand - he struggled very much.

ISABELLA POKE
. I am the wife of William Poke - these are his property; I did not know the prisoner, but I saw him in the shop.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he had seen a person come out of the prosecutor's shop and drop the bristles which be picked up. He received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 18 -
Confined One Month .

201.
THOMAS BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of November , 40 yards of flaunel, value 2l. , the goods of
John Muddell
; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Confined Six Weeks .

202.
JAMES ASPEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of November , 1 shawl, value 6s., the goods of
Caroline Brooks
, from her person

CAROLINE BROOKS
. I am single , and live in St. Andrew's-terrace, Waterloo-road, I am a dress-maker . On the 9th of November, I was in Arundel-street
, between five and six o'clock in the evening. I had a shawl on, and all on a sudden the prisoner suatched it off my shoulder; I turned, and cried Stop thief! I am sure it was him - I turned immediately, and he ran down the street - there was no person but him who could have taken it; he had no companion as far as I could judge - I ran after him and never lost sight of him, till he turned Water-street; I then turned, and he was in the hands of two officers - one of them saw him drop the shawl - I had not lost sight of him for a moment; I am sure he is the man.

SAMUEL PRICE
. I belong to the Thames Police. I heard the alarm, and turned into Water-street; I found the prisoner in custody of a brother officer - I went up, and the prisoner dropped this shawl from his person, I am sure he is the man.
Prisoner. Q. Did you see me drop it? A. I did, I was not a yard from you; that was about three hundred yards from where the prosecutrix lost it - she had not come up then.

JAMES LILL
. I heard the alarm, saw the prisoner run, and I took him; he said, "My tar, if you will make it all right for me, I will give you two sovereigns;" I had him by the collar, and he had his hand behind him, but I did not see him drop the shawl - I found a pair of scissors on him, and a watch-key.

Prisoner. Q. What did I say to you? A. You said you had lately come from sea, and had 4l. 15s. in your captain's hands, and you would give me two sovereigns; you said you were running after the man that stole the shawl, but there was no one near you; there was no one in the street but you - there had been some rioting just before, and the people followed them.
Prisoner's Defence. I was with the mate of a vessel, and he knew I was not the man who took it; I am a native of New South Wales, and was never in London before.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Transported for Life .

203.
ELEANOR CONNOLLY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of November , 15 yards of shirting, value 5s. , the goods of
Nicholas Morritt
.

JAMES SPENCER
. I am in the employ of Mr.
Nicholas Merritt
, a pawnbroker . On the 23rd of November the prisoner came into his shop while the lad was busy taking down articles, and folding them up on the counter - I was busy at the end of the counter; I turned, and saw the prisoner -I said, "What do you want?" she said, "Do you take in beads?" I said Yes - she said, "I will go, and fetch them;" I had seen her two or three times in the course of the day, and suspected her - I looked through the window, and saw something under her pinafore; I sent the lad to bring her back, and found this fifteen yards of shirting under her pinafore - she told me a woman had given it her to pawn for 1s.; I know it to be my employer's property.

GUILTY . Aged 12 -
Transported for Seven Years .

204.
JOHN FINNESSEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of December , 1 piece of wood, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
John Joseph Hickmott
.

JOHN JOSEPH HICKMOTT
. My father and I were taking down some premises, at the corner of St. Martin's-lane
- this wood belonged to us.

EDWARD CARPENTER. I saw the prisoner take a piece of timber from the corner of the ruins; he carried it out, and I followed him - he laid it down in Castle-court; I went down Tothill-street, and gave information-the officer took the prisoner, but the wood has not been found; there were eight or nine feet of it.
NOT GUILTY .

205.
THOMAS HUNT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of October , 4 coppers, value 3l. , the goods of
George Levett
.

GEORGE LEVETT. I am a copper-smith , and live in Whitechapel-road
. On the 22nd of October four coppers were taken from inside my door - I left them there safe at six o'clock when I went out, and when I returned they were gone; I did not see the prisoner till he was in custody.

SAMUEL PRENDERGRASS
. I took the prisoner on the 4th of November, about three hundred yards from the prosecutor's, between six and seven o'clock in the evening - the coppers have never been found.

WILLIAM WARNER
. On the 22nd of October I was coming up a yard, and saw the prisoner and two others standing at the corner of Mr. Levett's premises - I heard the prisoner say, "B-g-rd, if we don't have it;" and he went in and brought out the copper articles before him - the others lifted them on the prisoner's back, and he carried them off; I could not see how many there were of them-I knew the prisoner before; he did live with a butcher then - he sold fruit, and then he carried on a rum game.
Prisoner's Defence. I know nothing of the coppers - the officer said a woman and a boy came, and said they saw me take them.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .

206.
MARY LONG
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of November , 1 hat, value 10s., and 1 box, value 6d. , the goods of
James Whitehead
.

JAMES WHITEHEAD. On the 24th of November I went into a shop, and put down a hat and a hat-box, while I transacted my business - I went out, and left them behind me, not recollecting them; I called at another place in the neighbourhood - I then remembered them, went back, the lady in the shop told me a person had taken them, and she could not detain them, not knowing whose they were; I have never seen them since - I know nothing of the prisoner.

MARY ELIZABETH READ
. I did not see the prosecutor leave the hat and box in my shop, but a few minutes after he was gone the prisoner came in and took it away in a moment - I concluded she had left it; she had been to my shop several times - the prosecutor then returned, and I found my mistake: the prisoner came to my shop about a fortnight afterwards, and I had her taken.
- BERESFORD. I took the prisoner in Mrs. Read's shop.
Prisoner's Defence. I had been to the shop several times, and she never said a word about it till the day I was taken.

GUILTY . Aged 49. -
Confined Three Weeks .

207.
DENNIS McCARTHY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of December , 2 planes, value 2s. , the goods of
William Bryan
.

WILLIAM WHEATLEY. I am an officer. On the 3rd of December I saw the prisoner carrying these planes in Brick-lane, Spitalfields: I asked where he got them; he said from a sawyer, who had borrowed them of his master. and he was going to take them back - I took him to see if it were right; he told me of different people, but could not find any one - the next day I found the prosecutor.

WILLIAM BRYAN. These planes are mine. I lost them from Essex-street, Whitechapel
: I had them at work last Friday week, and missed them; the prisoner lived in that street.
Prisoner's Defence. I had them given me.

GUILTY . Aged 15. -
Whipped and Discharged.

208.
JOHN McGRATH
and
JOSEPH McCARTHY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of November , 1 pair of shoes, value 8s., the goods of
Ralph Wilcoxon
; and that the said John McGrath had before been convicted of felony .

GEORGE POWELL
. I am a Police-constable. On the 16th of November, I was opposite Mr. Wilcoxon's who is a boot and shoemaker - I saw the two prisoners and another boy
together; I saw McGrath take a pair of shoes from the window of the shop, and give them to McCarthy, who rolled them in his apron and walked away with them - McGrath then joined the other lad, and they walked on; I crossed over, and pushed McGrath into a shop - I then followed McCarthy down a turning, and took him; I found these shoes in the apron on the wheel of a cart down the turning.

WILLIAM PARDY
. I am servant to Mr. Ralph Wilcoxon - these are his shoes.
McCarthy's Defence. I saw them laying against a shop - Mr. Powell came and said, "Give me the shoes you stole;" I said I had none - I then put them on the wheel of a cart, and he took them.

GEORGE POWELL
. I have a certificate from Mr. Clark's office, of the conviction of McGrath, on the 28th of October, in the first year of his present Majesty's reign, for stealing a hat, value 5s., for which he was ordered to bewhipped - I attended the trial, and know he is the same person.

McGRATH -
GUILTY . Aged 10.

McCARTHY -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

209.
SOPHIA SMALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of December , 4 pairs of boots, value 16s. , the goods of
Ralph Wilcoxon
.

THOMAS BAKER
. I am a police-constable. On the 4th of December, at half-past eleven o'clock at night, I was in Tottenham-court-road - I saw the prisoner walking at a moderate pace; I saw she had a bundle, and I saw the ticket of the price of these boots outside - I asked what they were; she said a pair of shoes she had taken from a shop merely to have a lark - I asked where she had them from; she said she would show me - we went to several shops, but could not find which it was till we came to Mr. Wilcoxon's, who owned them.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How far was she from the prosecutor's shop? A. About three hundred yards - she was not in liquor; I cannot swear she had not been drinking - she gave me her right name and address at the watch-house.

WILLIAM PARDY
. I am in the employ of Mr.
Ralph Wilcoxon
. These are his boots, and were safe in his shop at half-past eleven o'clock, on the 4th of December-I did not see the prisoner till she was brought back.
Cross-examined. Q. Did she not appear as if she had been drinking? A. I did not notice her particularly - she gave her address, and that of two women who had gone away.
Prisoner's Defence. I was very tipsy, and am sorry to say it - I never was tipsy before.
The prisoner received a good character - one witness stated that his mistress would employ her.
GUILTY. Aged 34.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Judgment Respited
.

210.
JOHN ONSLOW
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of December , 1 cloak, value 14s. , the goods of
James Pincott
.

JOHN CONNOR
. I am a Police-officer. On the 6th of December I saw the prisoner run by me very quick with a bundle under his arm; there was a blue apron tied round it - he said it was a cloth pelisse; I said I would examine it - he then said it was a lady's cloak; I took him to the watch-house, and then found the prosecutor, who keeps a silk-mercer's shop at the top of Tottenham-court-road, and it was at the bottom that I took him.

WILLIAM MEADE
. I cut this coat out, and made it for Mr. James Pincott - I can swear to my own work.

HENRY JAMES COOK
. I hung this cloak at Mr. Pincott's door, about eight o'clock in the morning of the 6th of December - a young man gave me information, and I missed it.
Prisoner's Defence. I had to carry it.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Transported for Seven Years .

211.
THOMAS RICKETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of November , 6 half-crowns, 20 shillings, 2 sixpences, and 4 1/2d. , the monies of
Joseph Barrett
.

MARY BARRETT
. I am the wife of Joseph Barrett - he is journeyman to Mrs. Wilson, who is a baker, and I deal with her. On the 3rd of November the prisoner came to me, and said Mrs. Wilson would be glad if I would send her all the money I had, as the miller was in the shop; I gave him the money stated, and he went away.

CATHERINE WILSON
. The prisoner had lived with me about a month - I saw him go out of the shop; I never authorized him to go for this money - he did not return to me.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Confined Three Months .

212.
GEORGE ROSE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of November , 1 coat, value 2l.; 1 pair of spectacles, value 10s.; 1 gown, value 4s.; 2 yards of cloth, value 2s., and 1 basket, value 1s., the goods of
Elias Griffiths
, his master .

ELIAS GRIFFITHS. I live in King-street, Golden-square
, and am a tailor . The prisoner was my apprentice , and had been so for five months - on the 24th of November, I went out for half an hour, leaving him at home; when I returned he was gone - I missed a coat, a pair of spectacles, a gown, two yards of cloth, and a basket; he was taken early the next morning - he always behaved very well before.

THOMAS LUCAS
. I have a coat and gown, pawned by the prisoner on the 24th of November.

GEORGE SEAMAN
. I am an officer. I was on duty on the 25th of November, and saw the prisoner come down White Lion-street; I took him, and found these spectacles on him - I found this basket, which he had left at a public-house in Whitechapel, with two linen shirts in it.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY. Aged 16.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Transported for 14 Years .

213.
JOHN SCARBOROUGH
was
indicted for embezzlement .

JOHN KING
. I am a baker , and live in Woburn-buildings, Tavistock-square
. The prisoner has been twice in my employ, about six months each time; it was his duty to receive money, and to account for it every evening - I keep a book, and put down what he pays me; Jane Pope is a customer of mine.

JANE POPE
. I paid the prisoner several sums of money for his master; on the 6th of November I paid him 5s., and he gave me a receipt on this bill.

ANN SIMMS
. I paid the prisoner 3s. 9 1/2d. on the 6th of November - he gave me no receipt, as I always pay him ready money; I am cook in a family.

JOHN KING
. He never paid me either of these sums-I asked him about them, and he said he had not received them; I never went from the Saturday till the Monday without settling - he owes me 9s. now.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Confined Three Months .

214.
JOHN SULLIVAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of November
, 1 plane, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
John Young
.

MICHAEL COLLINS. I am a labouring man. I was at my dinner in a building in the Commercial-road
, and the prisoner came in there; I thought he was one of the carpenters, and told him to put some water in the glue-pot - he said, "It is not mine:" he then went up a step-ladder, and into another house - I sent a little girl after him; she told me where he was - I went and heard him up stairs in the next house: I went and told the watchman there was a strange man in the buildings - the watchman told me to go in front, and I went and saw the prisoner in the cellar, stooping, as if to pick up a two feet rule; he asked me if I knew a plasterer who worked there - we walked on, and talked together till we came to a public-house; I then took hold of him. unbuttoned his coat, and found this saw, this square, and this two feet rule.

JOHN MITCHELL
. I took the prisoner, and have the tools.

JOHN YOUNG
. This plane was mine, and was on the building.

JAMES WALDIE
. This is my rule - I was at work, and left it there; the prisoner did not work there, and had no right there.
GUILTY . Aged 21.

215. JOHN SULLIVAN was again indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of November
, 1 saw, value 6s., and 1 square, value 2s. , the goods of
James Simpson
.
JAMES SIMPSON. I worked on the building, and lost this saw and square.
MICHAEL COLLINS. I took the prisoner with this saw square, and the other tools.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Seven Years .
There were two other indictments against the prisoner.

216.
JOHN STEVENTON
was
indicted for embezzlement .

RICHARD BOUCHARD
. I am a publican, and am in the coal-business , in Chicksand-street
. The prisoner was my weekly servant , and was employed to receive money, which he was to give me on his return.

SARAH TIFFIN
. I know the prisoner - I paid him three half-crowns and a sixpence on the 25th of November, for two sacks of coals, which he brought about eleven o'clock in the morning.

RICHARD BOUCHARD
. He never returned to his parents or to me, and never gave me any account of this money - he was away till the 3rd of December.

GUILTY . Aged 13. -
Confined Three Months .

217.
MARY ANN TAYLOR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of October , 2 sheets, value 4s.; 1 pair of earrings, value 5s.; 1 bolster, value 5s.; 2 pillows, value 3s., and 2 pillow-cases, value 1s. , the goods of
William Ring
.

WILLIAM RING. I live in Greenhill's-rents, Smithfield-bars
. The prisoner hired a ready furnished room at my house three weeks before she was taken; on the 28th of October, during her absence, I went into her room, and missed the articles stated - I found in the room the duplicate of a pair of ear-rings, which had belonged to my wife and had been taken from the kitchen; I went out, and gave notice to a Policeman, if he saw them about to take them; she represented herself as a married woman, and a man lived with her.

ROBERT CUFFLIN
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Newgate-street. I have a pair of ear-rings, pawned by the prisoner on the 26th of October.

WILLIAM IVEY
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a pair of sheets, pawned by the prisoner.

JOHN VARLEY
. I have a bolster and two pillows, pawned by the prisoner.

DENNIS HINDLE
. I took the prisoner into custody - the prosecutor gave me two of the duplicates, which he found in her room.
WILLIAM RING. These are my property.

Prisoner. Q. How long ago is it that you had seen these ear-rings? A. It might be eight or nine months; in consequence of my father's death, they were taken out of my wife's ears to place black ones in.

Prisoner's Defence. When I took the room I found these ear-rings and a stud laying in the room - I took them to a pawnbroker, who said they were of no value; I wore them some time, and the prosecutor and his daughter saw them, and did not claim them - the sheets I meant to redeem.

GUILTY . Aged 31. -
Confined Six Months .

218.
WILLIAM ANSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of November , 34 Pence , the monies of
John Fowle
.

JOHN FOWLE. I am an oilman, and keep a shop in Anchor and Hope-alley, St. George's
. On the 15th of November I was in my back premises, and saw the prisoner come into my shop, and lean over the counter; he put something into his trousers pocket - he leaned over a second time, and while he was doing so I ran up; he got out, but I caught him just outside the shop; I asked what he had taken from the till - he said he had not touched it; I took him round, and did not miss any thing from the till; I asked what he had in his pocket - he said it was nothing to me; I then recollected that I had counted 5s. worth of penny-pieces, and put them behind my counter - I went to them, and found only 2s. 2d. left; on the prisoner I found 2s. 10d., which made up the 5s. - the prisoner said he sold ducks about the street; the officer took him.

CHARLES FALCONER
. I am the officer. I took him, and have the money.
Prisoner's Defence. He took me into the shop, said he had been robbed before, and he would make me suffer for all.
GUILTY . Aged 16.

Confined Six Weeks and
Whipped .

219.
WILLIAM BRIGGS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of November , 1 bed, value 1s.; 1 pillow, value 1s. 6d.; 1 bolster, value 1s.; 1 blanket, value 1s.; 1 piece of patch-work, value 1s., and 2 sheets, value 1s. , the goods of
William Moore
.

JAMES BARKWAY
. This property was taken out of a shed adjoining my house in Wellington-place, Stepney
; it belonged to Mr. Moore - it was distrained for rent, and put into my custody; I went out on the 5th of November, in consequence of information, and saw the prisoner about one hundred yards from my shed, carrying a bundle; there was an accomplice with him, but he got away - the prisoner dropped the bed, and I fell over it - I called Stop thief! the prisoner threw down the bundle.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did he not tellyou the other man gave them to him to carry? A. He said so at the Police-office - a child told my wife of this, but she is not here.

JOHN HULL
. I took the prisoner - I saw him coming up the road with something which he dropped, and the witness fell over it; I took the prisoner without a hat - he said before the Magistrate that the other man gave him the bundle to carry.
WILLIAM MOORE. This property was left there for the person it belonged to to fetch it away; I am answerable for it - I have been called William Thomas, but my name is only William.
Q. How do you write your name? A. William Moore, and I was christened William Moore.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you believe you were not christened
William Thomas
? A. No; I have some property disputed in Chancery, and it is in the name of William Moore - I have been called Thomas, and my aunt said my name was not Thomas.
Four witnesses gave the prisoner a good character; one of whom stated he would take him into his employ.
GUILTY. Aged 18.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor .
Confined Six Weeks .

220.
THOMAS GRUBHAM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of November , 4 pairs of shoes, value 22s. , the goods of
Joseph Johnson
.

GEORGE PAINE
. I was near Mr. Johnson's shop on the 30th of November; I saw the prisoner standing close to the window - I watched him; I saw him reach over and take these shoes from the shop, he ran away - I pursued and took him with them.

JOSEPH JOHNSON. I keep a shop in Tottenham-court-road
. These are my shoes.

GUILTY . Aged 14. -
Transported for Seven Years .

221.
THOMAS WILKINSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of December , 1 coat, value 4s.; 2 gowns, value 6s.; 1 ribbon, value 6d.; 1 petticoat, value 1s.; 1 pair of stockings, value 1s.; 1 south-wester, value 1s., and 1 cap, value 1s. , the goods of
William Henry Priestley
.

WILLIAM HENRY PRIESTLEY
. I have a barge , which I left safe at Limehouse
, between seven and twelve o'clock on the 4th of December; I was away from it for five hours - when I returned the cabin had been broken open, and the articles stated were gone; I know the prisoner - he works on the water.

JACOB MARKS
. I keep a shop at No. 10, Pearson-place, Brick-lane. Last Saturday evening week the prisoner came and asked me to buy a coat; I gave him 2s. 6d. for it - he refused it at first, but came back and took it - I gave the coat to the officer.

GEORGE BLAKE
. I am an officer. I received this coat from Marks.

SAMUEL KING
