. I was coming home last Sunday morning week, and found a number of things in Limehouse-fields - they had been torn to pieces and thrown away; these are them.
Prisoner's Defence. Two boys met me, and asked me to sell the coat. I did not break the cabin.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Seven Years .

222.
MARY SWAIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of August , 1 bolster, value 5s.; 4 pillows, value 10s.; 4 shirts, value 6s.; 4 blankets, value 16s.; 1 counterpane, value 8s.; 1 pair of pockets, value 1s.; 2 aprons, value 2s.; 3 yards of calico, value 9d.; 4 basins, value 1s., and 1 flat-iron, value 6d., the goods of
Esther Lala
; 1 pair of shoes, value 4s.; 1 shirt, value 2s., and 1 frock, value 1s., the goods of
Augustin Ballands
.

ESTHER LALA. I live in Union-street, Shadwell
. The prisoner was in my service for eight or nine months - I went to the Queenborough election with my lodger, and left the prisoner at my house; when I returned the prisoner was gone, and some of my neighbours had put a padlock on my door, to keep her from taking things away - I missed a great many articles which I have not found; the articles stated were among them - I made inquiries, and the prisoner was taken on the 23rd of November; I asked what she meant by doing so; she said she knew all about it, and she would go with me quietly.

ROBERT MARSTON
. I am a Thames Police-officer. I went with the presecutor to Greenwich and took the prisoner; she said she had destroyed the duplicates, but would give me a list of the things.

JOHN RALPH LAWSON
. I have a sheet, a pair of pockets, a pair of shoes, and some other things pawned by the prisoner.

JOHN JOHNSON
. I am a pawnbroker. I have five articles, but I did not take them in, and do not know who pawned them.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I rented a room at her house while my husband was at home, and paid her 7s. a week; when my husband went to sea with the man who lived with her he left me his monthly money, and when she was gone to Queenborough, I took these things with the intention of redeeming them with my husband's money, which she was in the habit of receiving.

ESTHER LALA
. She was my servant ; I took her in out of charity - I went to Queenborough on the 30th of July, and returned on the 3rd of August; I left her plenty to eat and drink while I was gone, and 2s. to get her some beer.

GUILTY . Aged 42. -
Transported for Seven Years .
Fifth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

223.
HANNAH WIMPROY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of December , 1 pelisse, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Peter Pige
.

ROBERT WALL
. I am a Police-officer. on the 1st of December I was in Church-street, Bethnal-green
, at half-past two o'clock; I saw the prisoner at Mr. Pige's shop, in Church-street - she unpinned this pelisse, and it dropped on one side; it had been pinned to some more pelisses - she walked away about ten yards; she then returned, took it down, and put it under her shawl - when she had gone about twenty yards I took her back; she said, "Do not take me, I never did any thing before in all my life; for God's sake don't take me."

THOMAS COOMBS
. I am shopman to Mr. Peter Pige, a pawnbroker, in Church-street, Bethnal-green. This is my master's property; it had been pinned under the shopwindow - I had seen it about five minutes before the officer brought the prisoner with it; it has our private-mark on it, and is worth 1s. 6d. - I had seen the prisoner about the shop for several hours.
Prisoner's Defence. I picked it up; I hope you will have mercy on me - it is the first time I was ever accused of felony; I have brought up a family in that parish, and never had a key turned on me.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 65.

Recommended to Mercy by the Jury . -
Confined 6 Months .

224.
WILLIAM HOLMES
and
PATRICK COSTELLO
were indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of November , 2 saws, value 6s., the goods of
John Curry
; and 1 saw, value 3s., the goods of
John Cook
.

JOHN CURRY. I am a carpenter and live at No. 1, Hertford-place, Somers'-town. I lost these saws on the 23rd of November, but did not miss them till the following Monday, when I came to work; I had left them in the back-parlour, concealed, under some bundles of laths, in a house in Jermyn-street, Piccadilly
- I saw them again at Marlborough-street; these are them.

EDMUND DARNLEY
. I am shopman to David Jones, of No. 185, High Holborn - he is a pawnbroker. I have two saws pawned by Holmes on the 23rd of November, one for one shilling and sixpence, and one for two shillings, in the name of
John Parker
- this one saw was claimed by Cook.
Holmes. Q. What time did I pawn them? A. Between six and eight o'clock; I can swear you pawned them- I can swear to your person, you came into the last box by yourself - we were not busy at the time.

PETER DIXON
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker, in High-street, St. Giles' - Costello pawned this tenant-saw with me on the 23rd of October, between seven and eight o'clock, in the name of John Costello; I am certain he is the person.

THOMAS GOOK
. I am a constable. On the Saturday in question, I saw the two prisoners in company, in Jermyn-street, near the building where this affair took place, I think it was about seven o'clock - they were walking and standing about, and a third person was at a distance; in a day or two afterwards, I heard the men had lost their too's. and went to the pawnbroker's and found these saws- this one was claimed by Cook, but he is sick, and could not attend.
Holmes. Q. Did you see us in Jermyn-street? A. Yes, on the day of the robbery, and I took you ten days afterwards.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Holmes' Defence. On the night he says the robbery was committed, I never saw this prisoner.

Costello's Defence. On the Monday week following, I was walking with Holmes, and Gook took us - I know nothing of the saws, and never saw them; if I had been guilty I should not have pawned them in my own name.

HOLMES -
GUILTY . Aged 17.

COSTELLO -
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Seven Years .

225.
WILLIAM PRITCHARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of November , 1 writing-desk, value 3l., and 2 spoons, value 1l. , the goods of
Richard Leigh
.

CHARLES UNDERWOOD
. I am in the service. of Mr. John Underwood, of Providence-row, Islington. On the 12th of November, I was passing Mr. Leigh's door, in Islington, between one and two o'clock - I saw the prisoner at the front door, and another person on the pavement; there is a garden in front of the house, fenced off from the street - I did not stop then, but in a few minutes I returned and saw the prisoner in the parlour, and the window was open - the other man was still on the pavement; I went home and left my tray, and then went back, and saw the prisoner leaving the premises, and the other man had the desk; they ran different ways - I took the prisoner, who made some resistance; the other man ran away - the desk was carried back and delivered to Mr. Leigh: I saw two silver spoons found on the prisoner.
Prisoner. Q. Did you see my face? A. Yes, I did; and when I went by again I saw you in the parlour, and knew your person.

PHOEBE LEIGH
. I am the wife of Richard Leigh - we live at Cloudesley-cottage, Islington
; I went to the door when the prisoner was taken - my husband's desk was brought to me; Mr. Camp searched the prisoner in my presence, and found in his trouser's pocket, one silver table-spoon and one tea-spoon - the desk had been on the side-board in the parlour, and the spoons in the cupboard; the desk is worth 3l., and the spoons 1l. - the tea-spoon had a mark on it by which I know it, and I believe the other to be mine.

THOMAS CAMP
. I was sent for and took the prisoner; I found the two spoons on him.

ALFRED HARRIS
. I am a Police-officer. I took the prisoner, and the desk was delivered to me.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going to Holloway, and saw something shining on the grass; I took it up, and it was this tea-spoon - about half a yard further I saw the table-spoon - I put them into my pocket, and had got but a few yards when the witness took hold of me; I asked what for, he said, "Never mind. you will know presently;" a person went and knocked at the prosecutor's door, with the desk.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .

226.
JOSEPH COWEN
was indicted for
stealing on the 25th of November , 1 watch, value 1l.; 1 watch-chain, value 1l.; 2 seals, value 2l., and 1 pair of spectacles, value 1l., the goods of
John Whale
from his person .

JOHN WHALE. I am a footman to Miss Hall, of Lamb's Conduit-street. On the evening of the 25th of November I was coming out of Guildford-street, into Lamb's Conduit-street
, and three men laid hold of me - one took hold of each arm, and one walked before me; it was about five o'clock; I cannot recollect who they were, the fright was so great I lost my memory - I think the prisoner is one, but I cannot swear to him, my eyes are so bad - I was pulled along the street all the way to my mistress' door; they robbed me at the door, and went away; I was very much alarmed, and have been very ill ever since - I can hardly walk; I lost a silver watch, a gold chain, two gold seals, and a pair of spectacles - they were all young men dressed like gentlemen; they were too sharp for me - I am a poor old man; I cannot swear to the prisoner, but I firmly believe he is one.Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You say you were frightened, and lost your memory, then how can you pretend to have a recollection of any one about you? A. I wish you to examine my witnesses; I am so ill I can hardly stand, but I believe the prisoner is one; I saw one of them was a tall man: it was getting dark; it was about ten minutes past five o'clock - I cannot say whether the prisoner had a black cravat on or a white one; he had a brown great coat and a black hat - I saw him when he was taken to the station-house

WILLIAM PORTEOUS
. I am a police-constable. On Thursday, the 25th of November, about five o'clock in the evening, I was on duty in Lamb's Conduit-street - I saw the prosecutor opposite me, on the left-hand side: there were three persons with him; one in front, and the other two had hold of each of his arms: the prisoner was one, and he had hold of his left arm - I had seen the prosecutor two or three times, and knew where he lived; I saw him at Miss Hall's door, and the prisoner struggling with him: the prisoner then ran away, and two other persons, who I believe were the persons I had previously seen with him -I followed the prisoner into Theobald's-road, and Great James-street; I there saw him put out his hand to a person, whe looked back; he then escaped down Red Lion-street; the prisoner ran on, and I stopped him in Chapel-street - I had not lost sight of him from the time I saw him at Miss Hall's door; I had noticed the person who had hold of the prosecutor's arm had a black mark of courtplaister on his temple, and when I took the prisoner I saw he had it on his temple; when I took the prisoner he struck me on the breast, and told me to keep off - I seized another man shorter than him at the same time, but was obliged to let him go - I took the prisoner to Miss Hall's door, and as soon as the prosecutor saw him he said, "That is the man who robbed me of my watch;" the prisoner denied all knowledge of it; the gas-lamps were not lighted - there was a light from an oil-shop and a linen-draper's, about twenty yards off.

Cross-examined. Q. Then the prosecutor swore positively to him? A. Yes; he said."That is the man who robbed me:" he did not say then that his memory was quite gone - I seized two men, one with each hand; they had both run from the place: my attention was partly directed to the other man; I am a little short in my memory- I cannot say how the third man was dressed: I first saw the prisoner at the corner of Great Ormond-street - they were then opposite a light, and I saw the black patch on his face; it was not because I saw the prisoner had a black patch at the station-house that I swear to him - I saw it at first; they were then about twenty doors from Miss Hall's- I did not notice the other men; I noticed the prisoner attentively - I believe I should have known him without the black patch; I found on the prisoner 2l. 14s. 3 1/2d., a penknife, and a head of a pin with a stone set in silver; I believe it is a brooch: he told me he was returning from his work - I asked where he lived; he said in Pitt-street, but he did not tell me who his master was, nor where he lived - I found nothing belonging to the prosecutor.
JURY. Q. Did you notice the prisoner before he arrived at the door? A. Yes, by the light of the oilshop.

SARAH MILLER
. I live in Duke-street. On the 25th of November I was going to Miss Hall's, and saw John at the door, and several men about him; he had hold of one man by the coat or sleeve - I do not know which; I was alarmed, and said "What is the matter?" he said,"I have been robbed by three men; I don't know whether this is the one who robbed me, but he is one of them;" the man got from him, and ran off - I ran and cried Stop thief! I did not see the man's face, but he was a tall man, and had a great coat on: he ran from the door, and two joined him - I cannot speak to either of their persons.

Cross-examined. Q. It was rather dark? A. Yes; but there were lights burning in Mr. Kinton's shop, a grucer's opposite, and in an oil-shop next door - the gas was not lighted; I did not notice any patch on the man's face.

Prisoner's Defence. I was returning from No. 34, Mecklenburgh-square, where I had been to put up some curtains, but the laths and brackets not being there, I could not finish them - I saw two or three persons talking very jocularly, and when I got to Miss Hall's door there was a cry of Stop thief! and two persons ran away; I pursued one of them down to Chapel-street, where the Policeman took me back to the door, and the old gentleman certainly said, "That is one of the parties;" I stated where I had been at work, and the inspector gave the officer a note to go there, and he found it was correct; I was taken to the office, where I told where I had been, and what I had been doing - One man stated that he knew me to be a thief, and all my companions had been transported; but this I deny in toto.
WILLIAM PORTEOUS. I went to No. 44, Mecklenburgh-square, and the servant stated he had been at work there about two hours.

HENRY CORBET
. I am servant to Mr. Oxenford, of Mecklenburg-square. The prisoner had been at work at my master's till between three and four o'clock; he left to get some laths to fit up the parlour curtains.

WILLIAM HENRY SHUFFREY
. I had employed him to go to put up the curtains that day; and he had worked for me about two years before, but had left me till that day.
NOT GUILTY .

227.
JAMES NEALER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of August , 72 bottles, value 18s. , the goods of
George Hughes
.

JOHN TOWNSEND
. I live in Goswell-street
, and am a paper-stainer. I know the prisoner, he was in the employ of Mr. George Hughes; I have purchased wine of him, and the prisoner delivered part of it on the 2nd of August - he came to my house, and said he was sent by Mr. Hughes for empty bottles, and I delivered him five dozen, for which he gave me this receipt; they were due to Mr. Hughes, and I gave them to the prisoner as his servant - Mr. Hughes had charged me for the bottles, and the charge was to be taken off when they were returned: (receipt read.)
2nd of August, 1830. Returned five dozen empty bottles for G. Hughes. - J. NEALER.

GEORGE HUGHES. I am a wine-merchant , and live in Goswell-road. The Prisoner was in my service till July;I expected to receive these bottles from Mr. Townsend: I had charged him with them, and upon their reaching me, I should have given him credit for them; they were worth 15s.

JOHN SMITH
. I am a Police-constable. I took the prisoner; I did not make him any promise or threat, but he said he had not taken more than twenty dozen, and he had done it to support his father.

Prisoner's Defence. On the 23rd of August, Mr. Hughes' son said to me, "James, we are very short of bottles, do you know where there are any owing;" I said Yes, at Mr. Townsend's - he said, "Go and fetch them;" I went, and got them - I did not see my master; he was denied, as he was afraid of being arrested for debt - I gave the bottles to his son; and said he had better put them down - he said, "I shall not; come in and have a game at marbles."
MR. HUGHES. He had left me on the 2nd of August.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Transported for Seven Years .

228.
EDWARD BAILEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of December , 1 hat, value 5s. , the goods of
Edward Jeffs
.

EDWARD JEFFS
. I am a hatter , and live in New-street, Covent-garden
. I had a hat in my window for sale on the 8th of December, about nine o'clock in the evening; I had seen it about half-past eight - about nine o'clock I heard a noise in the window, and heard something fall inside the shop; on hearing that, I looked and missed the hat - I looked out and saw the prisoner about twenty yards from the door, carrying the hat in his hand before him; he turned his head round, saw me, and ran away -I followed him, and he dropped the hat; he was stopped before I lost sight of him - this is the hat, it is worth five shillings.
Prisoner's Defence. I was going home - this gentleman called Stop thief! and took me.

PATRICK ROENAYNE
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner: this is the hat I received from Mr. Jeffs.

GUILTY . Aged 15. -
One Month and
Whipped .
OLD COURT. WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 15.
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

229.
WILLIAM WILSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of August , 1 watch, value 2l. , the goods of
Ann Robinson
; to which he pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 26.
Transported for Seven Years, to commence from the expiration of his former sentence . (See page 54)

230.
THOMAS JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of December , 1 pair of trousers, value 12s. , the goods of
William Alleston
.

WILLIAM ALLESTON. I live in Duke's-row, Pimlico
. On the 11th of December I saw the prisoner in the custody of an officer, with these trousers, which were taken from the cill of my door.

JOSEPH BURTENSHAW
. I am an officer. I was on duty on the 11th of December, and saw the prisoner and another lad running down Brewer-street, Pimlico - I followed them across Vauxhall-road into Wilton-road, where I overtook the prisoner with these trousers; I asked what he had got - he said a pair of trousers, that he was going further on with them; I asked how he came by them; he said the lad who was running on before had given them to him, and he was going to a field to look at them - I first saw him about twenty yards from the prosecutor's.
Prisoner. Q. Who had the trousers when you first saw us? A. I cannot say.
Prisoner. He did not ask where I was going with them - I was informed I should not be tried this Session.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Confined Six Months .

231.
THOMAS KEYS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of December , 1 sovereign and 17s., the monies of
Colin Campbell
, from his person .

COLIN CAMPBELL. I am a mariner . On the 4th of December, I was in liquor in the early part of the day -Lawson was with me; we were together, and between eight and nine o'clock at night, I went to a public-house, remained there for an hour, and fell asleep - when I awoke, I found myself quite sober; the prisoner came in afterwards with another man - I had no conversation with him; they were both strangers to me - I said I had occasion to cross the water, and being unacquainted with the road, asked Lawson to show me the way to Execution-dock to cross the water; the prisoner heard this - I and Lawson went off together, about half-past ten o'clock in the evening; I had in my trousers pocket, a sovereign and 21s. 6d. in silver - there was a half-crown among it; I paid for two pints of beer in the public-house, and put the money into my pocket, and am sure it was safe - I had my hand on Lawson's shoulder, talking to him as we went along; the prisoner came up behind me suddenly. put his hand round me, and into my trousers pocket - he took out my money; a half-crown and shilling fell on the ground - I was stooping to pick it up, and the man who was with him came forward to push me over the money, but I got it up, and sung out for the Police; the prisoner ran away, and called to the other, "Come along Tom;" they were both out of sight in a moment - I had seen them both in the public-house, and swear positively to the prisoner; I felt in my pocket, and all the money was gone, except the half-crown and shilling which I picked up - the prisoner was taken last Monday week.

THOMAS LEWIS
. I am a Policeman. I was on duty in Back-lane, Shadwell
- the prosecutor called me; I went up, but the men were gone; the prosecutor told me his story.

ANDREW LAWSON
. I am a blacksmith. The prosecutor said he would give me a pint of beer to show him the way to Execution-dock; I did not know him before- the prisoner came in with another man while we were having the beer - they sat down by us; they heard the prosecutor ask me which way we were to go, and they followed us; the prosecutor had his hand on my shoulder - the two men followed us in Back-lane, and the prisoner laid hold of him by the arm, and some money fell on the ground; the other man stooped down, picked something up, and called after the other man, Tom; they both ran away - I had seen the prisoner selling fish in the streets before - I swear he is the man.

Prisoner's Defence. I had been to Billingsgate, and brought some herrings; I went into the public-house to sell them - a young man was sitting in conversation with him, and he asked me to drink with him; I came out, and sold my herrings at the Coach and Horses - I went home, went to bed, and on Saturday morning was apprehended; I am innocent.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Life .
Before Mr. Recorder.

232.
THOMAS McALLISTER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of December , 17 lbs. of spelter, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of the
London-dock Company
.

ROBERT WHITE
. I live in Charles-street, Commercial-road, and am a labourer, in the employ of the London-dock Company. I saw the prisoner coming from a pile of spelter in the docks, and stopped him; he had these 17 lbs. of spelter buttoned up in his coat - it was concealed by his jacket; he begged me to let him go, saying he was very much distressed; I detained him till the officer came - he had nothing else about him, and appeared in distress.

JAMES SLATER
. I am a constable of the London-docks
. White brought the prisoner to me - I searched him; I do not think he had any property about him - he was not in the company's employ at that time, but he has worked as an extra man.
The prisoner pleaded distress.

GUILTY . Aged 45. -
Confined Two Months .

233.
GEORGE MUNN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of December , 1 cloak, value 15s. , the goods of
Charles George Collins
.

WILLIAM AUSTIN PAGE
. I live with Mr. Charles George Collins, a draper , of Chelsea
. On the 8th of December this cloak laid three feet within the door - I had seen it safe about an hour before it was taken; he does not sell ready-made clothes; I did not see it taken - the prisoner was brought into the shop with it about a minute after the alarm; I took it from him - master has no partner.

JAMES GUGYEAR
. I am a groom to a gentleman in the neighbourhood. On the 8th of December, about twelve o'clock, I was going home to dinner, and saw the prisoner take the cloak down out of the passage, and put it into his apron; the cloak was close to an inner door of the shop, but not within it; he walked off with it - I caught him by the shoulder, and said, "Bring that back to Mr. Collins;" I took him back, and Page claimed it as Mr. Collins.

GEORGE THATCHER
. I am a constable. I was passing the house - the prisoner was delivered to me with the cloak; I searched him, and found a large clasp knife and a tobacco-box on him, but nothing else; I did not know him before.(Property produced and sworn to)
Prisoner. I was never charged with any thing before.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Confined Two Months .

234.
EDWIN ROBERT RANDALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of October
, 3 silver spoons, value 6s.; 1 gold ring, value 10s., and 1 sword-helf, value 4s. , the goods of
Ann Randall
, widow ; and
JOHN MORRIS
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, harbouring, and maintaining the said Edwin Robert Randall, well knowing him to have committed the said felony ; and
ISAAC SIMMONS
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the said 3 spoons, well knowing them to have been stolen .

ANN RANDALL. I live at No. 9, Brewer's-row, Palmer's-village, Westminster
, and am a widow. I lost this property on the 31st of October - I had been robbed several times before; I put these things into a pocket-book, and put the pocket-book into the mattress of my bed - I do not know on what day they were taken, but they were safe on the 26th of October; I have reason to think they were taken on the 30th, but I did not miss them for three weeks after that - Randall is my son, and lived in my house; he was fourteen years old last June - he was not in the house immediately that I missed them, but I saw him come in the next day, and I wished him to leave the house; he usually lived in the house.

Q. Did he ask why you forbid him the house? A. He knew there was a reason for it, but he did not know I had discovered the loss; I told him I had lost them, and suspected him - he denied it at first, and then said, "Don't make such a bother about your things, you can get them back again;" I said, "How am I to get them back?" he said, "Go to Bill Page, and he will tell you all about it;" I have never found the things - the spoons were silver, and worth 2s. each, the gold ring 10s., and the aword-knot 4s.

WILLIAM PAGE
. I was formerly a pot-boy. On the 31st of October I was out of employ, and am so now; I lodge in Little George-street, Westminster, and know Randall - I was standing against the Castle public-house, with the prisoner Morris, when Randall came up, and said he had some old silver to sell; he spoke to me first - Morris made answer, and said, "Oh, have you?" Randall said Yes, he had, but he did not know where to go and sell it; he had not got it with him then; I afterwards saw him give a parcel to the prisoner Simmons, and heard him say, in Simmons' hearing, that there were three silver spoons in it; Randall and Morris went along together with Simmons, till they came up to the Fighting Corks, which is not many minute's walk - I stood across the road, and Morris called me over; I remained outside the house.

Q. What occasion was there for you to wait? A. I waited there till they came out; they all three came out together, and then Simmons went one way, Randall and Morris another; I saw the parcel delivered to Simmons before they went into the public-house, but never saw what was in it; Morris is a person who jobbed about - I had known him about three months; I did not know Randall had stolen the things from his mother - he said he and another boy had stolen them from a person across the Park, and that he had stolen six of them; he did not mention his mother - he did not mention the name of the person from whom he had stolen them, but said it was a jeweller's shop, by some square - I made him no answer when he told me this; I gave information about it in about a fortnight, when his mother came to me and accused me about it - she apprehended me, and said I had bought the spoons, and that he had said he sold them to me for 3s. - I had not bought them, nor made any agreement to boy them; Randall was taken up that morning, Morris next day, and Simmons the day after.

Cross-examined by MR. SMITH. Q. The mother accused you? A. Yes; I had never seen the spoons - the parcel was in brown paper, and what it contained I do not know, except that Randall told me it contained three spoons, and that he had stolen six, but three he had for himself, and three the other boy had; that one was almost worn through in the middle - Simmons was not by when he said that; I was to have none of the produce; I followed him to see what he sold them for - I did not see the money given, but he said he sold them for 2s. 6d.; I swear that; he gave him the money in the public-house; he told me so when he came out - I did not hear him tell Simmons he had stolen them; I only know that he bought them by what Randall said, and he showed me the 2s. 6d. - I am not swearing now.
COURT. Q. You are speaking on your oath now? Witness. Yes, I am speaking what I saw, and what he told me.

MR. SMITH. Q. Do you know that every thing you say now is sworn? A. Yes; I was a pot-boy about four months ago; I had been out of place about three months, when this happened - I had been jobbing about; I was never taken up, or charged with any offence before - I have been in custody till the present time, to give evidence - I was never convicted of any thing; I cannot say Simmous did not give him back the spoons, nor that they were Mrs. Randall's; he said he sold the three which he had, to Simmons.

JOSEPH WILKINS
. I am a Policeman. I apprehended Simmons on the 27th of November, in Orchard-street -I did not then know where he lived; he was walking along Orchard-street - I had been looking after him before; I asked him if he had bought some silver spoons of three boys, at the Fighting Cocks, Dartmouth-street, and believe I said he had better tell the truth - I had a warrant, and went and searched his place, in Corbett's yard, Petticoat-lane - I found nothing there; I forgot to state that I took him from the watch-house to Tothillfields, to see Page, who was there; I asked Page if that was the man; he said, in his hearing, that it was; (I had heard Page's account before) - Page said, "You are the man who bought the spoons at the Fighting Cocks, Dartmouth-street;" Simmons said, "You had better look at me again, and be sure that you don't swear wrong;" he persevered in it - Simmons said, Page would swear wrong, and denied it - I have not found any of the stolen things; Simmons was in the watch-house when I went to his place; I saw his daughter there - he had directed me to that place as his - I did not apprehend the other prisoners.

Cross-examined. Q. He did not hesitate in the slightest degree to tell you where he lived? A. No; I found his daughter and two or three of his children there; they did not object to my searching, but behaved particularly civil - he has a large family; I knew nothing of him except seeing him about Pye-street, and Duck-lane on his business.
Randall's Defence. I wish to say, I never said anything of the kind, either to my mother or to Page - as to my fellow-prisoners, I never beheld them till they were at Queen-square.

Morris Defence
. I know nothing of Randall - I never saw him, and had no connexion with him - I never spoke to Simmons.

Simmons' Defence. I am as innocent as a child unborn- I never knew the prisoners till I was apprehended, and when the Policeman charged me with the spoons, he said,"These are the boys;" I said, "I don't know them."

MRS. RANDALL. Only my father daughter, and three children, live in the house - I knew Page as potboy at the public-house we dealt at; he did not come to our room at all - I never saw Morris at the house; he keeps company with my son.

RANDALL -
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Transported for Seven Years .

MORRIS -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

Confined Six Months . and
Whipped .

SIMMONS -
NOT GUILTY .

235.
THOMAS WEST PRICE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of October , 5 necklaces, value 100l.; 2 pairs of ear-rings, value 10l.; 2 brooches, value 5l.; 1 pair of bracelets, value 5l.; 4 rings, value 80l.; 1 watch, value 15l., and 2 gold chains, value 10l. , the goods of
Eleanor Dyott
.

SECOND COUNT, stating them to be the property of
Eleanor Thompson
.
MR. PHILLIPS conducted the prosecution.

ELEANOR DYOTT. My maiden name was
Eleanor Thompson
. In October last I lived at Hope-cottage, Walham-green
; I was married to Mr. Dyott, but have been divorced
- I rent the house. In July last the prisoner and his wife came to lodge at my house: he had no conversation with me respecting my property till about two months after that - I took him to lodge there for protection, it be - a lonely situation, and I had no man-servant; he asked me if I had any articles of value, as it was a had neighbourhood, winter was coming on, and there might be robbers-I said I had a gold watch and a few trinkets; I had given them apartments free of rent, for the purpose of protecting my house - a short time after I told him I had the watch and trinkets, he said if I would inform Mrs. Price of my affairs, as to my property, she could give evidence in case of a robbery - I did so according to his desire: the prisoner afterwards said he thought my jewellery and trinkets would be safe in the well under the carpet in the drawing-room, which is on the ground floor - the carpet conceals the well; I had talked to him at different times about my valuables, and on Thursday, the 21st of October, the prisoner put them into a hole in the garden; I first mentioned that place to him - he said he would dig the hole, and put them there; I went with him to hide them in the hole in the garden, between six and seven o'clock in the morning; he placed them in the hole himself - he put all the articles stated in the indictment into the hole; the value of the whole together was very near, if not quite, 400l.; one of the sets was presented to me by an old friend on my marriage, and I do not know what that cost; I sent my maidservant out of the house while we put them into the hole; Price had desired me to send her out of the way while he put them there, that there might be no witness to know of it - mine is a detatched house; the garden is walled round- there are no houses that could overlook the hole in the garden, I should suppose not: I suppose the nearest houseis about as far off as a very strong person might throw a stone - this was on the morning of the 21st of October; the prisoner went out that evening, saying there were thieves about - he returned, and said he was shot at; I had heard no shot - he had been out a few minutes; I do not know whether he had been in the garden or where; he said there must be somebody about in the garden, and I said that in the morning he and I must search for the property - this was about seven o'clock in the evening of Thursday, the 21st of October; when he came in, I went with him to the side of the house which looked over the garden, but neither saw or heard any body moving about the garden - he went with me, and fired a pistol out of the window; I heard nobody exclaim that they were wounded, nor saw any body - the garden wall must be six feet high; it was a middling night; the garden is about the length of this Court, or longer - if there had been any robbers I must have seen them: next morning, the 22nd, I went with the prisoner's wife to look in the garden for my property; the hole appeared as we had left it - his wife dug up the mould for me, and dug out the box, but the jewellery was all gone except this little article (producing a locket set with fine brilliants) - this was left behind, covered up in this little case.

Q. A person taking the things out in a hurry might have overlooked that? A. It was tumbled in hay, and in a small red leather case - it is worth 60l.; I had asked the prisoner the night before to go into the garden with me in the morning, and he said it was proper to go, but when I asked for him to go next morning he was gone to town, and I sent for his wife; he had asked me the value of my property, and I said it was some hundreds - he came home that afternoon about one o'clock; I said to him "The property is all gone" - he laughed, and said he must go back to town; he staid an hour, walked all about the garden, and said it was very probable the property was on the premises; the house is in the middle of the garden: he then went back to town, returned in the evening, and asked a man to sit up all night with him in the house, and suggested to me that it was necessary for them to sit up to fire pistols, and they fired pistols all night - they fired, as near as I can judge, about twenty times.

Q. Did you find any body dead about the premises in the morning? A. No - I told him next morning it was very miserable to live there, and I thought I should go away; he said I ought not to go, for if I did he would go away, and I ought to stay, and not be frightened away - he said on the following evening that it was pretty certain the property was about the premises, and if he found it I should be under an obligation to him; he offered me the keys of his boxes to be searched when he came in from town at one o'clock on Friday - I had not charged him with any robbery, not given him the least him of it; I did not search his boxes - I had not the least suspicion of him at that time. On Sunday morning, the 24th of October, about ten o'clock, I was in the garden with him - he was searching for the property among the trees, and found a case of very valuable jewels, worth about 70l., hid in the ivy-tree; I have not brought it here - it is as large as my hand - he called to me, "Look there!" and took it out of the ivy - I could reach it; we had talked a good deal about my loss in the interval; I had said I was afraid it never would be necovered, and it would put me to an expence to take steps - I have got no more of it back; that still missing is worth from 200l. to 300l. -Ledbetter, the officer, was sent for, to whom I described what had occurred; he desired the prisoner to come to Bow-street to give an account of it, and the Magistrate held him to bail.

COURT. Q. The prisoner pointed out the jewel-case in the tree? A. Yes - I had not seen it before, and should not have seen it; it was quite concealed - it would be impossible for a person who did not know it was there, to find it.

Cross-examined by MR. HURCOMB. Q. Who fires the pistols off at your house now? A. I have left a man named Arthur Maggs to take care of it; he tells me he never has occasion to fire, but I do not live there now, I live at Brompton; I left the house two days after the robbery - the prisoner fired pistols almost every night after the robbery, but I understand none have been fired since he left; there was no firing before he came to live there -I am timid, but Barnwell, whom I bought the house of, lived in it with his wife and family before the prisoner came - I went there in August, 1828; I have been divorced twelve years and more - I lived in the house some years since I have been separated from my husband; I know Akers, he is the carpenter - I employed him at the time of this accident; when the prisoner said he had been fired at, I went up stairs with him, and looked out of the window, it was about seven o'clock in the evening - we had no particular alarm that night, but I was under constant apprehension; this was the night of the day the property was deposited in the garden - it was gone next morning; Mr. Price desired the servant should be sent out while the things were buried - he sent her to the Post-office, and I sent her.

Q. Did you send her to the Post-office to ask for a letter for A. B.? A. No, Price did - I had shewed him a brooch with my father's hair in it, and he saw the outside of the rest of the things; he advised their being put under the carpet - it was not my advice.

Q. Will you swear he did not recommend you to place them at your banker's? A. He mentioned that people put property into banker's hands by way of security; I told him I had no banker - he did not advise me to send them to a man who did not exist.

Q. Did he not, supposing you had a banker, recommend you to send the things? A. I have said as plain as I could speak that he said property was safe in banker's hands, but my saying I had none, stopped the conversation; he said if I had a banker it would be proper to send them there - I think this was on Thursday evening, the 21st of October, when he went out, and said he had been shot at.

Q. Do not you know that it was when you talked of putting them into the well in the drawing-room? A. I cannot say, to be certain, when it was; he proposed putting them into the well in the drawing-room - I cannot say in what room I was in when he proposed it, for we were continually talking about the well; I first told him there was a well there - it could not be seen; he spoke about alterations in the house, and I said, "Here is part of this house you would know nothing about," and I might have saidsome weeks before that the well was a secret good place for any property; he proposed to put them there on the evening they were put there; I might have proposed it a month before - the carpet was drawn over the place after they were put there, and there was a heavy chest of drawers near the place; I believe he put a tack or two in the boards - I do not know of his borrowing a screw-driver to get the boards up; I was present when they were taken out - there were a few small nails to be taken out; there seemed no difficulty in getting them up - when he put them into the well he packed them up in paper and hay, and sealed them; my bed-room, the dining-room and drawing-room are all on the ground floor - both the dining and bed rooms command a view of the hole in the garden; the entrance to Price's apartment is on the other side of the house - his sleeping room is over my bed-room, but does not look on the garden; my maid-servant slept pretty near me, on the ground floor, and close against the drawing-room - she slept in a passage between the drawing and bed-rooms.

Q. Were you not frequently in the habit of alarming Price at night, calling him up, expressing your alarm of thieves being in the house, and requesting him to come and stay with you? A. He came to me the first serious alarm himself, and said he thought there were thieves about - that was three or four four weeks before this, and after that I sometimes called him up: Akers did not sleep in the house on the night the robbery was supposed to have taken place - I am quite positive of that; he was there that day, I believe; he was in the garden when the prisoner found the case in the ivy - he was not at work there; it was Sunday - he had come to make an excuse for not coming to set up the night before, as Price had desired him; I opened the case in the presence of Akers and the prisoner, when it was found - I swear that.

Q. At the time the things were put into the garden, had you any workmen about the premises? A. I had Akers, but nobody else that day - I believe not; I am pretty sure Fox, the bricklayer, was not there - I will not swear it, but am pretty sure his work was done then; the prisoner had a key of the garden gate, and I had one- I had deprived my maid-servant of a key; she did not let the prisoner in and out - he let himself in and out; he usually went to town at seven o'clock in the morning- he left at eight the morning after the robbery; he usually returned about five, and often later - I did not have a fire lighted in the parlour after the things were deposited in the garden - I thought Price a designing man, but did not at first suspect him of this; he came to lodge with me in consequence of an advertisement which was inserted by my agent, Mr. Dyer. of Knightsbridge - it was headed, "Gratis;" it was stated in the advertisement that it was by way of protection, but that was my motive; I left it to Mr. Dyer to inquire into the prisoner's respectability - I went to Mr. Dyer after the robbery. the prisoner's wife said he should be there, but I thought it best not to meet him - they came to lodge there on the 22nd of June; I never lived alone in the cottage - Barnwell, his wife, and daughter lived there before; Mr. Robinson never lived there - I was formerly acquainted with Mr. Robinson, but he was never at the cottage; there was not a crim. con. trial about him, that was about Mr. Dunn - I was the wife of General Dyott; I believe he is now living - I was never in France with Mr. Robinson; I never travelled with him - he has lived in a house with me; persons have not been in the habit of coming backwards and forwards to my cottage - not since I lived there; Barnwell only left the house a few months before the prisoner came - no men were in the habit of coming there, except a carpenter or so, or an attorney on business - I never charged any other person with the felony; about a year and a half ago a good deal of my money was embezzled - received for my trustees; not stolen, but embezzled - I indicted a person named Eager for it: he was found guilty, and was six weeks in the House of Correction - I never made a charge of any kind against Clark, or any gardener; I missed some silver spoons, but charged nobody with that - they were not found; I did not go by the name of Miss Innes - I was for a short time, without any satisfactory reason, called Mrs. Egerton; I know no reason for it - it was very unwise advice; my accounts were never made out in the name of Innes - I pay ready money for almost every thing; I have very few accounts - I have printed my memoirs; I was never confined in any asylum as not being of sound mind - I had but one watch; I hardly ever used it - I think the prisoner has seen the watch; he did not abscond - he continued at the house after the charge, till he removed at the suggestion of a gentleman; I wished him to remove, but he continued there a fortnight - the Magistrate suggested that he should remove, and he did; he gave bail on this charge - he never advanced me a farthing; he has arrested me, but what for I do not know.

Q. Will you swear he never paid for coals for you? A. I have not received the coal-merchant's bill - he persuaded me to let him order a chaldron of coals, but whether he paid for them I do not know; I never pawned my trinkets, except when my money was embezzled, and I was under the necessity of raising a little.
COURT. Q. Was it before or after he was held to bail that he arrested you? A. After.

DANIEL LEADBETTER
. I am an officer. In consequence of this transaction, I went down to make inquiries at the prosecutrix's house - the prisoner went to Bow-street, and was bailed there; I saw the place where the jewels were buried - the hole was at the bottom of the garden wall, so that no person could see where the jewels were deposited; no person in the adjacent houses could overlook the place.

MRS. DYOTT re-examined. My income is 800l. a year. Prisoner's Defence My Lord and gentlemen of the Jury - The endeavours of my counsel I hope will convince you of my innocence of the offence - Gentlemen, nothing but malice has been the reason of her appearing on a charge so unfounded, which I hope to be able to prove by my friends, and restore my character which previous to this transaction was unsullied! when I consider I am the third or fourth person who have unfortunately been subject to similar inquiries to the one in question, nearly all of whom proved their innocence after having been subject to very heavy expences as myself, I hope to convince you Mrs. Dyott's character will not stand in the scale with my own, and I hope the Jury will prove her statement false and unfounded, after hearing my witnesses - I know nothing of the property; I never saw it- she cannot prove I ever saw it; I advised her to remove it to a banker's, and when she stated she had no banker, I can prove I advised her to lodge it in the custody of a pawnbroker, even if she paid interest, and she told me she paid 15 per cent. interest on it.

HENKY AKERS
. I am a carpenter, and live at Parson's-green - I have lived there about nine years, and have some houses in the neighbourhood. I have worked for Mrs. Dyott, and was at work for her on Thursday, the 21st of October, on her premises, in the house - I am certain of the date; I did not hear of this robbery till the Sunday - I was watching at Mrs. Dyott's on the Friday night; it was after the property had been taken, I am quite sure - I was not watching there the night before(Thursday) I am quite sure; Friday was the only night; I was watching - nothing particular happened that night; pistols were fired off by Mrs. Dyott's wish several times - she wished pistols to be fired several times - I did not take off my clothes all night - I laid down on the bed; Mrs. Dyott called me up - she said nothing particular to me; she merely called Price - I heard her call him; he answered, and then I got up - Mrs. Dyott said she thought somebody was getting in at the drawing-room window; we were then on the ground floor, in Mrs. Dyott's bed-room - she bad removed her bed up stairs that evening; nothing else occurred - we went to examine, but saw nothing.
COURT. Q. About what time of night was this? A. About half-past three o'clock in the morning, I think - the pistols were fired that persons might know there were people in the house.

MR. HURCOMB. Q. Do you remember on Sunday being in the garden with Mrs. Dyott and the prisoner? A. Yes - she wished me to help to take down the ivy which grew by the wall; Price was taking it down at one end of the wall, and I at the other, as Mrs. Dyott wished to have the wall whitewashed - she said she thought it should be whitened, that by looking out of window they might see persons about the house; while Price was taking it down, Mrs. Dyott called me aside to explain what work I was to do next day - Price came up, and laid hold of a piece of ivy which I had left half down- he pulled it quite down, and there was the leather case in the ivy; I saw it found there - Price could not have put it there at that time, and I do not think that Mrs. Dyott could, unless she did it while I was away at the harbour, which is at the end of the wall, where Price was pulling it down; Mrs. Dyott said she was very glad she had got that, that was all she cared for, but there was another red morocco case, which she should like to get, but that was not of so much consequence - the locket in the red case had been found at that time; I was not called in to take care of the premises before the Friday.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How did you know the locket in the red case had been found? A. Mrs. Dyott mentioned it on the Sunday morning, while we were in the garden; she said there was another morocco case besides the one found - I have not the slightest notion who put the case in the ivy; Price had finished pulling the ivy down at his end - the case was found at the place I was at; I did not see it till he discovered it - I have known him three or four months; Mrs. Dyott asked me to watch the premises on Friday - that was the first and only time I sat up - Price and I were not in the same bed; he was in his own bed, not in the same room; he did not tell me of the robbery that night - I never heard of it till the Sunday; he never told me Mrs. Dyott had complained of losing her jewels - I never heard it from him, nor from Mrs. Dyott, nor the servant, till Sunday - that I swear; I never said I had any idea who robbed the premises - I have no recollection of having said so.
COURT. Q. Did you never express any opinion about it? A. Never, I am quite sure.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Why tell me you did not recollect? on your oath, did you never tell any body you thought you knew who robbed the premises? A. I never said any such thing, nor that I did know who robbed Mrs. Dyott, nor that I and Price shared the plunder between us; I was in no public-house the night after the robbery- I was at the Royal Oak on Sunday; I have been there about three times - Moore keeps the house; I was drinking with him on the Sunday after the robbery, about eleven o'clock in the morning, and I think I left there about seven in the evening - we were not great friends; I was not drinking all the time - I should think we had three or four pots of beer, but no spirits; I was not altogether intoxicated - I was not perfectly sober; I am not certain whether I had four or five pints - I do not consider that I drank five pints altogether; I was rather elevated.

Q. Now, on your oath, when you got a little elevated, did you not tell Moore something to this effect, that you and Price made a good night of it, and never made a better night than the night Mrs. Dyott was robbed? A. I only say I never said such a word, nor any thing of the kind, nor to that effect, nor did I mention the red morocco case to him, nor a red case, or red pocket book, nothing of the kind; we were not particular friends - I was not with him all the time; I did not talk with him about the robbery at all, to my knowledge - I said nothing to him about the robbery; I rather think I mentioned finding the case in the ivy.

Q. Now, if you think it rather might be mentioned, how came you to swear that Mrs. Dyott's robbery was not mentioned? A. I cannot say - I rather think the jewelcase was mentioned; I am not certain of it - I did not know what the case contained; not when I was at the public-house.

COURT. Q. Now recollect what you have said before; do you mean to assert, that at the time you might have mentioned the jewellery-case being found, you did not know what it contained? A. No, I did not know.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Do you mean to represent, that when Mrs. Dyott's box was handed to her, she did not open it to see if the jewels were gone or not? A. She took it in doors - she did not open it in my presence; she had taken it in before she spoke of the red morocco box being more valuable - she did not open it in the garden to see if the jewels were safe, nor even shake it; she took it in doors, then came back, and said there was another large morocco box, she should wish to have that found if she could; that the one lost was more valuable than that- she said she did not care much about that as long as she got the blue one, that was not of so much value; I understood the one not found to be the most valuable - it was after that I went to Moore's.

Q. How came you to swear you did not know the box contained jewels at the time you was at the public-house? A. I did not know what it contained; I have sworn she said the jewels were more valuable in one, than that which was not found, but I did not know what it contained, no more than what she said - she merely mentioned it in the garden; I heard her say something to that purpose.

Q. Do you remember going a little further with Moore, and saying, what d - d fools you were to restore any part of the property? A. No; I swear nothing of that kind took place; I was not speaking to Moore about the jewel-box which we found - I never meationed it to him; I do not think I said a word about it.

Q. Could you forget whether you spoke of it to Moore? A. I think I might forget: it was found about half-past ten, and I went to Moore's between eleven and twelve - it was not spoken about; it was not mentioned to my knowledge - I do not recollect speaking to him at all of Mrs. Dyott; I had never fired out of window before; I do not recollect telling him I had been up all night, firing out of window; I do not think I told him a word about it - I might have done so and forgot it; I am quite sure I never told him it had been a good night for me - I do not recollect talking to him about the robbery.
Q. Were you sober enough to know what you was doing? A. Most likely not; I do not recollect at all - I was not sober.
Q. Did you not fix the quantity of beer drank at five pints in eight hours? A. It might be more; I am almost positive I never said any thing about its being a good night &c.

Q. Do you mean to repeat that you were so sober you never mentioned any thing of the kind, and could not without remembering it? A. Yes; I never did mention to him any thing about finding the box in the ivy, and firing out of window - I never did.

Prisoner. I was so flurried when called upon for my defence, I did not at that moment recollect it; but being provided with memorandums which I had written, I should feel particularly obliged to be allowed to state it in the presence of Mrs. Dyott, and she will not do me the injustice to say I did not wish her to act by my determination - about twelve o'clock on the Friday, Mrs. Dyott searched for the property; the maid-servant came to my office with a letter, who from I do not know, but understood it was from Mrs. Dyott - it intimated a wish that I should meet her at Mr. Dyer's, at Knightsbridge; I left my books loose on the desk, took the coach and went to Dyer's- he said Mrs. Dyott had just left, and advised me to recommend her to go to Bow-street; he said he was not aware that she had the property she reported to have lost, or he would have advised her to put it into his hands - I left him, intending to advise her to return with me to Bow-street; I went on Baston's coach, and overtook the maidservant at Queen's-elms, who had rode with me to Mr. Dyer's - I saw Mrs. Dyott, who repeated to me her loss; she spoke in a very careless manner, which induced me to believe she had not lost what she represented; I immediately offered her all my keys, to look at my rooms, if she suspected me - I, of course, knew she had lost them, from what I heard at Mr. Dyer's, and what she told me herself; she said he shad no suspicion of me, and refused to search- I stated that the next day was a Board-day, that I was very busy, and should be obliged to start very early in the morning of Friday, and it is said that betrayed my guilt; now I left at eight o'clock that morning, and left word with Akers to tell Mrs. Dyott I would be home in the middle of the day, and she did not wait for my coming home, but sent to me, as I have represented; I begged her to return with me to town, and go to Bow-street, for I would do my best to serve her; but in consequence of the expences she said she had incurred from the loss she repeated to your Lordships this morning, she said she did not care about it, for the thieves had got all they could have - she would not allow me to go to Bow-street; I was obliged to go to town to finish some reports, and on my return in the evening I found Akers had not left, but was to sit up the greater part of the night, and on Saturday morning, about eight o'clock, I rapped at Mrs. Dyott's bed-room door, and asked if it was her wish I should go to Bow-street and make some inquiry - she said No, it was not, and she would not give me authority to go; I went to the office, returned in the evening, and on Monday morning, before I left my bed-room, Akers called to see me about the limewhiting of the walls at the back of the house - I immediately accompanied him and Mrs. Dyott; (he had been on Saturday pulling down ivy,) the case was found on Sunday morning, and as soon as Mrs. Dyott had got the case, I never saw the contents - she took it herself from the ivybush and fell down in hysterics; I caught her in my arms, but she never let it fall out of her hand - she wished me to order an omnibus to call for her at two o'clock, and she took with her to Brompton a trunk - what it contained I do not know; I never saw it - she promised to return on the Monday, to search for some other things, as it was probable, having found one, she might find another; she never came, and on Tuesday the officers saw the premises - I went with them into the drawing-room, of my own accord; Ledbetter said it was a curious circumstance - I said it was, but I was perfectly innocent; he wished me to meet him at the office on the following day at twelve o'clock - I said I could not at that time, having business of importance to do; two o'clock was appointed, and at two I arrived, with the intention of seeing Mrs. Dyott, but I was surprised to find a statement made very much to my prejudice - I knew nothing about it; I remained on the premises for a week - perhaps your Lordships will ask Mrs. Dyott if I did not wish her to go to Bow-street for advice.

MRS. DYOTT re-examined. I have attended to what the prisoner has stated - he told me after the robbery that it would be proper to make inquiry at a public-office; his wife had sent him the letter by my servant, and she proposed my meeting him at Mr. Dyer's, but I declined - I went to Mr. Dyer's immediately, and did not see him - he came to my house about one o'clock that day; I was a little overcome when the jewel-case was found, but did not go into hysterics; I am not hysterical.
Q. Did the prisoner support you? A. He stood close to me at the time, and I was a little agitated.

JANE TICKNER
. I was in Mrs. Dyott's service for thirteen months - I heard her and the prisoner talking about moving some valuables from the well in the room-drawing - I wasin the kitchen, they were in the hall, and I could distinctly hear what they said; I heard Mrs. Dyott say she thought they had better be put out in the summer-house; Price said, "Ma'am, I think they are safer where they are," and he told her she had better put them into her banker's hands - I am sure I heard that, and she said, "Oh, no; I think putting them into the pawnbroker's would be a great deal better;" this conversation was on the Sunday night before the robbery - they were put into the garden on the following Monday morning; I donot know that, but I was told so afterwards - I was sent to the Post-office rather before seven o'clock in the Monday morning; Mrs. Dyott sent me - she said, "Jane, go for this letter A. B. to the Post-office, and you need not hurry yourself;" the Post-office is about ten minutes' walk from there.
COURT. Q. Was this on Sunday? A. No, on Monday morning.
MR. HURCOMB. Q. Do you remember the Thursday night following? A. Yes, the night before the property was missed.

Q. Now, be very particular; was Akers in your mistress' house on that Thursday night? A. Yes, he was in the house all that night; he never went out, and he was also there all Friday night - on both nights: I let him in and out; I had a key of the garden-gate, which I always kept myself - I used always to let the prisoner in and out; Mrs. Dyott had two keys for her own use, besides the one I had - Akers was at work in the kitchen on the Monday before the robbery; there was no other workman about the premises - he sometimes came to work at six o'clock, and sometimes at five; he was not in the house when I was sent to the Post-office - the door to the prisoner's part of the house was different from Mrs. Dyott's, but she used to have the doors of the house locked up by half-past five in the afternoon - the garden-gate leads to both entrances; if the prisoner went to the hole at the bottom of her garden the shortest way from his own door, he must get over a wooden partition, which is very high, by Mrs. Dyott's bed-room - her bed-room window is opposite it; he could not have got over that fence - he would have broken it down; it is slight like a verands.

Q. Then, if he had gone at any time to that part of the garden he would have had to go from his own door all round by Mrs. Dyott's window? A. Yes, and then she must have seen him - he must pass her dining-room, drawing-room, and bed-room windows.

Q. Do you remember whether between the Monday and Thursday, Mrs. Dyott had a fire made in the dining-room? A, Yes, she had one in the drawing-room and dining-room - she was in her bed-room the whole of the day; she did not say why she had the fire - she would not suffer me to go in there; it was not usual to have a fire in the dining-room - she used to sit in the kitchen before; I was there before the prisoner came to live there Mrs. Dyott was always afraid of thieves before they came - I am quite sure Akers was in the house on Thursday night, and I heard a noise that night with the glass door in the hall; I went, and told Mrs. Dyott - she desired Price not to go out; this was about one o'clock in the middle of the night - the noise was outside the house; Mrs. Price went into her own room when I told her - nobody was sleeping in that room; she changed her bed after Thursday night, and went up stairs - Akers was up, I, and all of us - Mrs. Dyott was up part of the night, and Mr. and Mrs. Price were up the whole night; I alarmed Mrs. Dyott at one o'clock - she then went up stairs; the window looked into the garden, I heard her desire Mr. Price to fire at that man - she had been looking out of window for some time - the whole evening - I was down in the hall, where my bed is; Price got up upon this alarm.
Q. What do you mean by his getting up; what did he do? A. He dressed himself, and was with Mrs. Dyott the whole night.

Q. Had Price gone to bed before one o'clock? A. No, but I saw him dressing himself; he had gone to bed - he went to lay down on his bed, and Mrs. Dyott came after him again; I do not know whether Mrs. Price was in bed- I was not in the room; I saw her up after one o'clock: Price and Akers were up stairs watching the men about the premises - Mrs. Dyott said she saw three men, and pointed towards them; she said to Price, "There, I see three men plain; shoot at them;" on my oath I heard her say that; it was about an hour after Price was up - he shot at them, and she asked if she should see them dead tomorrow morning; he said he did not know - Price did not go out the whole night; Mrs. Dyott told him to fire through the glass if he saw any one - he lifted up the window to fire at the three men; I am sure Akers was in the house at the time; he fired once.
COURT. Q. Are you quite sure he fired on the Thursday night, at the three men? A. Yes, I am quite sure.

MR. HURCOMB. Q. Do you remember at what time Price left the house next morning? A. A little after seven o'clock - I was sent to the Post-office on the Monday: Mrs. Dyott sent me to Chelsea for some brocoli on the Friday morning, and when I came back she told me to go to Mr. Price, and she gave me a letter - that was about nine o'clock; I gave him the letter, and he came back to the cottage with me immediately - he took the coach, and stopped at Mr. Dyer's, at Knightsbridge; I went on, and Mr. Price overtook me - I went on to the cottage with him.

Q. You have lived about thirteen months with Mrs. Dyott - have you ever seen any singularity of behaviour in her? A. I think she is a very bad woman, Sir; sometimes three or four gentlemen came to the house in the course of a day - they have staid there about an hour or two; she told me not to come into the room unless she called - Price had no key to the gate; some time before I went to my mistress she went by the name of Miss Innes; I never heard her answer to that name - my father served her with milk, and used to send her bills in that name; I know she went by that name in the village - it was four years ago; I have seen her walking about the house without any clothes on whatever, none at all.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Is this as true, as that Akers was at the house all night on Thursday? A. Yes, I swear he was there all Thursday night; he was in the house two nights.

Q. What was he there for on Thursday night? A. She said she was surrounded by thieves, and he had better stay- she gave him a pistol; she said this about five o'clock: he had been working there all day - I saw her give him the pistol, powder, and ball; she gave him, I should think,about 100 bullets; the powder was in a dram, a little tin box - I saw it opened, and saw the powder in it; she opened it before me - the bullets were not in any thing; Mr. Price gave him the bullets - Mrs. Dyott sat up all night making bullets; Mr. Price made them out of some shot - I saw him making them in his own kitchen; he had the shot in a small fire-shovel - there was about half a pound of shot; I and Mrs. Dyott were in the kitchen with him when he was making the bulltes; perhaps there was not so much shot as would fill that little thing (an ink-stand); I sat by looking at him - he made one hundred balls, I think - I did not count them; he made them out of not quite that thing full of shot; it was middling size shot - he made them on the Tuesday night before the Thursday; I saw him give the hundred balls to Akers - he said, "Akers you can take these balls, and if you hear any body you can fire;" Mrs. Dyott gave Akers the pistol - Price had a pistol himself; he threw himself on the bed on Thursday night.
Q. Merely took a little nap in his clothes? A. Yes - I saw him get up and dress himself afterwards; he did not go to bed twice.

Q. When was it he got up and dressed himself? you told his Lordship you were all up the whole night? A. Mrs. Dyott told him she was annoyed with thieves about one o'clock; Mrs. Dyott can see very well - I heard her point out the man to Price, and then he fired; it was about half-past one o'clock - it was getting rather lighter, light enough for him to have seen the three men; I am sure of it - I did not look out of window, but I know it was quite light; she could see them in the garden - she said she saw one with a smock-frock on; Price was looking out of window at the time - I do not know where Akers was when Price fired; he was in the house - I saw him there that night, and spoke to him; I have no doubt of his being there - I am sure he sat up both Thursday and Friday nights - Mrs. Dyott missed her things on Friday morning.
Q. Of course, she made a dreadful fuss about her jewels in the house? A. Yes, I did not hear her make a fuss; I have sworn just now she did make a dreadful fuss.

Q. Then did she make a terrible fuss about it on the Friday? A. Yes, she told both Price and Akers on the Friday that she had lost her jewels - I heard her tell them - they both said they were very sorry about it.

Q. Suppose Akers has sworn that he never heard Mr. Dyott had lost her jewels till Sunday morning, would he not have sworn what is not true? A. Yes. When my mistress sent me to the Post-office, she told me I need not hurry: Price was there that morning - I am sure it was not Thursday; it was Monday, for I went to my mother that morning - I could have quitted Mrs. Dyott with a week's notice, but her housekeeper was mistress over me.

Q. But would you stop in the house with a bad woman that walked naked through the house? A. I did not see her before - it was about two months ago; it was after the robbery - the robbery was about a month ago.
COURT. Q. Is it true or not that you have seen your mistress walk naked through the house since the robbery? A. Yes.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Be careful now - when did you see her walking naked since the robbery? A. A fortnight before I left; it was in her bed-room in her house at Walham-green - it was about a month ago; it was after the robbery - it is longer than a month ago.

Q. Two months? A. Not so long as that - I do not know what month it was in; a month is four weeks; she walked up and down stairs naked, all through the house; every body could see her - Mr. Price could see her if he came in, and the gentlemen who called, if they came; she walked even without her shift, in cold weather.
COURT. Q. How long after the robbery did you leave her? A. About three weeks after.

Q. Do you mean to swear she staid three weeks in the house after the robbery? A. No, she went away on the Sunday morning, but she came backwards and forwards, and changed her clothes, and put on clean ones.

Q. Is that what you mean by walking naked? A. And then she went up-stairs in the same state - I was left to take are of the house when she left; Mr. Price remained there - he and Mrs. Price must have seen this; Mrs. Price was at home all day - I never mentioned to any body that I had seen her walking naked - not before I came here; Yes I did, I mentioned it to Mr. Smyth, the prisoner's solicitor, about three nights ago - I live with my father and mother; I never mentioned it to them, nor to any body but Mr. Smyth, and Mr. and Mrs. Price - I do not know how many times I have seen her walk naked; it was not half a dozen times - Mrs. Price never saw it, for she never went into any apartment unless I was with her, and Mrs. Dyott never went so before Mrs. Price - sometimes she undressed in the drawing-room, and sometimes in the dining-room.

Q. That was not walking about the house naked? A. No; she would go into the garden - she did not go there quite naked; she went up-stairs from the lower part of the house quite naked; Akers was not in the house when she did it - I never told him of it: I told Mr. and Mrs. Price of it several times - I saw her every morning, and when I saw her I told Mrs. Price; I saw Mrs. Dyott walking naked every morning for the last two months I was with her; this was for two months running - I did not tell Akers of it till the last day or two; I had mentioned it to him within the last day or two.

THOMAS HIGGINS
. I keep the White Hart public-house, at Walham-green. I became bail for the prisoner on the 27th of October - Mrs. Dyott called on me on the 28th; she said she understood I had become bail for Mr. Price - I said I had, and I thought him a respectable man; she said she had lost some property, but she did not suspect him at all - she never suspected him; it was his own fault that he had the investigation - that he wished to have the investigation; she told me he had advised her to leave the property in the drawing-room, and not remove it - I was called away to draw some beer, and that conversation ended.

COURT to
HENRY AKERS
. Q. Had you any bullets delivered to you at any time? A. No; I never had - there was never one hundred bullets delivered to me, or any; I was in the house, watching on the Friday night -I laid down part of the time; I was not there on Thursday night, I am quite sure: and am quite sure that on Thursday night no bullets were delivered to me to fire at thieves -
Jane Tickner
never told me any thing about Mrs. Dyott being dressed or undressed; I never heardany thing of the sort from her - I knew her by seeing her in the house.

GEORGE BOLLOND MOORE
. I am a carpenter and joiner. In October last I opened a beer shop at Fulham, on a Sunday in October; six or seven weeks, ago Akers came there, about eleven o'clock in the morning; I had not heard of this robbery till he came - he staid till about nine o'clock in the evening; he and I had a pint or two of beer -I am not allowed to draw in the time of service, and he drank by himself afterwards - I have known him three or four years, and have worked with him: he said to me, "I have made a good thing of it," and said he had been at work at our old shop, Mrs. Dyott's; he said, "We were d - d fools not to take the one away that we left behind some ivy;" he called it a box, and said it was left behind some ivy against the wall - I am sure he said, We; he said Price and he were there together at night - that he went out and fired a pistol in the air, and then ran back and told Mrs. Dyott that some robbers out there had fired at him - he had been talking of himself and Price; I am sure he said, "We were d - d fools not to take away the box left behind the ivy, as well as the rest" - and said it was worth 60l.

MR. HURCOMB. Q. You have left Fulham now? A. No, my wife is there now - I have lived at Sheen, in Berks; I did not go away from there, leaving my wife and family chargeable to the parish, for I had no wife then, nor have I done so since - I have not been there for these five years.
MR. PHILLIPS, Q. You left your wife at Fulham? A. Yes, to-day; I have not been to Newbury these three years - I have worked at Fulham these five years, but have been home once.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Transported for Seven Years .

336.
WILLIAM SANDERS SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of November , 1 pair of boots, value 8s. , goods of
Benjamin Ward
.

JOHN EMERY
. I am in the employ of Benjamin Ward, of Islington
. On the 26th of November, between eight and nine o'clock in the morning, I was inquiring about these boots, and missed them; I had seen them safe five minutes before in the shop, and in about half an hour I found the prisoner at the station-house with them - I am sure they are my master's boots.

THOMAS HOBBS KING
. I am a Policeman. Between six and seven o'clock in the morning I saw the prisoner in conversation with another young man, coming down White Lion-street, Pentonville, about a quarter of a mile from Ward's shop, Smith crossed knocked at a street-door, and asked if they wanted buy lemons; the other kept the same side of the way - the prisoner was not admitted to the house; I went up and asked what he had got under his great coat - he said a pair of shoes; they were a sort of half-boots - I asked him how they came in his possession; he said he brought them of a man at Hornsey, that the man carried a bag, and he gave 5s. 8d. for them - I took him to the station-house: no lemons were found on him - seeing the other man had another pair of boots under the breast of his coat, I went back for him, but he got away - the prosecutor lost two pairs; I found out Emery, who claimed them.
Prisoner. Q. There was nobody with me? A. I saw them both talking together, each having a pair of boots.

JOHN EMERY
. I know these boots by the figures on them - Mr. Ward made them: they sell at 9s. 6d. - we lost two pairs that morning, but found only these.
Prisoner's Defence. There was a young man before me, but not with me; they gave 8s. as the full value at Hatton-garden.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Confined Six Months &
Whipped .

237.
JOSHUA SPURLING
and
SAMUEL JACOBS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of December , 50 lbs. weight of iron, value 5s. , the goods of the
Independent Gas-light and Coke Company
.

THOMAS FULLWOOD
. I am engineer at the Independent Gas-light and Coke Company. They act under that name, and are authorised to prosecute and defend in that name; I have seen the Act - this iron was laying on the ground in their yard at Haggerstone
- I had not particularly noticed it for a week before it was taken; it was five bars -I found it at the Police-station on the 7th or 8th of December, about eleven o'clock in the morning - it had been made to a pattern of my own invention: I found about a hundred weight and three quarters of it there - I believe the prisoner had been employed on the works by the commissioners of the road, to wheel ballast away which they had purchased.
Spurling. Q. Had you seen me on the works with a barrow? A. I think I have; but I am not certain of Jacobs.

WILLIAM SMITH
. On the 7th of December, about a quarter before seven o'clock, I was on duty as a private patrol of St. Leonard, Shoreditch - at the corner of Union-street, leading towards Kingsland, I saw Spurling wheeling a barrow - Jacobs was walking alongside of him; I crossed over, and asked what they had got there - they said, "Some iron:" I asked where they brought it from - they said,"From Kingsland, from Mr. Perry's marine-store shop;" I said they must go with me to the watch-house, and while I was talking to them, Jacobs slipped two shovels from behind his back - I put them into the barrow, and with the assistance of the Policeman, took them to the station: the shovels have not been claimed - I was present when Fullwood saw the iron at the office, and claimed it; I was sure that Perry did not keep an iron shop at Kingsland.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Spurling's Defence. I went down to my father's to do some work; I was coming up and happened to see the barrow in the road - Jacobs said, "Will you give me a help along with it?" I did not know but it was his property, and wheeled it for him - Smith said, "What have you here?" I said, "Iron;" he said, "I can't let you go;" I said, "Well, I may as well go, it is not my property."
