WILLIAM SMITH. Jacobs said he brought it from an old iron shop - Spurling did not contradict him; he said he had wheeled the barrow for him.

SPURLING -
GUILTY . Aged 21.

JACOBS -
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined Two Months , and Whipped.
Second Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

238.
GEORGE TURNER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of December , 1 hearth-rug, value 12s. , the goods of
James Absell
.

JAMES ABSELL. I am an upholsterer , and live in Goldsmith's-row, Hackney-road
. On the 9th of December this hearth-rug was taken from the further end of the shop- I saw it safe half a minute before, but did not see it taken; I sent my boy one way, and I went the other - it was about five o'clock in the afternoon, and about eight I found it at a pawnbroker's in Old-street-road; while I was in the shop, claiming it, the prisoner came in to pawn a carpet - the pawnbroker said he was the lad who had pawned my rug.

WILLIAM BIRD
. I am shopman to Mr. Burgess, a pawnbroker, in Old-street-road. The prisoner pawned the rug at near eight o'clock last Thursday night.
Prisoner. Please your worship, it was six o'clock when I took the rug.

Witness. I think it was about eight - I lent him 5s. on it; he said he brought it from his sister, and gave me the direction, No. 4, Bath-street, in the name of
George Turner
he came again while the prosecutor was there, to pawn a carpet, which has not been claimed; I think he brought the rug later than six o'clock - it was near eight that he came the second time.(Property produced and sworn to.)

JOHN BOLT
. I am a Police-constable. The prisoner was given into my charge for stealing the hearth-rug - I found no duplicate, or any thing on him.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going along Kingsland-road, at a quarter before six o'clock, and met a man, who gave me the rug to pawn at Miller's for 6s. - I thought he said 3s., which I asked; but when I went to him and gave him the 3s., he said I was to have had 6s. - he went with me to get it out again, and sent me to Burgess'; they would only lend 5s. - I came out and gave the man the ticket and money; he then sent me to pawn the carpet - the prosecutor said the rug bad a string tied to it.
WILLIAM BIRD. There was a string tied round it when the prisoner brought it - the carpet is now at our shop.

JAMES ABSELL
. I am sure the rug is mine.

GUILTY. Aged 15. -
Judgment Respited
.

239.
MARY WHITE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of November , 7 shillings, and 5 pence, the monies of
John Robinson
, from his person .

The
prosecutor did not appear NOT GUILTY .

240.
JOHN COOKSEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of December , 2 pairs of stockings, value 20s.; 3 pairs of stockings, value 14s., and 1 pair of mittens, value 3s., the goods of
James Robertshaw
, from his master .

JAMES ROBERTSHAW. I am a hosier, haberdasher, and linen-draper, and keep a shop in Oxford-street
. The prisoner was in my employ for seven months and twenty-one days - I had a good character with him from a respectable house in Bond-street. On the 6th of December I had discharged him, and was about to pay his salary - he said he would take his trunk, and call in half an hour for his salary; I had suspicion of him, and called him up into the drawing-room - I put rather forcible question to him; I certainly said he had better state all about it - I found I could get nothing from him, and called in a Policeman; the key of his box was found; after a short time, the Policeman opened it in his presence - a pair of ladies silk mittens were found, which I conceived to be mine, but cannot positively swear to them; they are worth 3s. - I thought it useless to search the box further at the house, and sent it to the Police-station; I was present there when it was searched; the two pair of silk stockings, and three odds ones were found in it - they are black, spotted with white; I have three stockings corresponding with the three odd ones; they are a peculiar stocking, and I can say decidedly they are mine - the pair are very fine, and not general in the trade, but I will not swear to them; the odd one I will swear to.

Cross-examined by MR. BALL. Q. Do not you know that the prisoner has been able to save a little money at his former place? A. I am not aware of it - I have heard of it since the prosecution; I have since heard from a relation that be has a little money in the stocks - I have seventeen persons in my shop; I know nothing about the prisoner giving any offence to the cook about any gruel; I know of no dispute between him and the young men in the shop about the cook - if he was ill, gruel would have been allowed; he may have been sent out on errands just before he left; I first saw his portmanteau when it was brought into my drawing-room by Mr. Rutherford, who has been twenty years in my house; it was locked - the key was not to be found, but the prisoner at last produced it; I know nothing of its being left down stairs open for four hours - I know nothing of the box having been searched before; when he was brought into the drawing-room it was sometime before the key could be found; I swear to the odd stocking - they are not a common manufacture, but very uncommon and peculiar; I think there is not another pair in England like one of these - I had only one pair of that pattern, and it was made to my own peculiar idea.
Q. Could not other persons have put them into his box? A. How is it possible for me to say, when I do not know where his box was?

JOHN HOWARD
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner - the box was brought to the station-house by a porter; these two pairs and three odd stockings were found in it - they appear to be the fellows of these produced by the prosecutor; the prisoner produced the key of the box, and I opened it.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I know nothing of the stockings being in my portmanteau - it was in the kitchen, exposed to all the house, from six o'clock in the evening till nine at night, as I was sent out by Mr. Rutherford; the box was opened three times before it was taken to the station-house - once it was opened by the porter, as he said Mr. Rutherford wished to open my things; I opened it - he examined it, said there was nothing belonging to him, and seemed satisfied; he went up stairs to fetch my money, as I supposed; he then came down, and said Mr. Rohertshaw wished to look it over - I took it up into the drawing-room to Mr. Robertshaw - he stepped up to me, and said I had been robbing him; he opened my box - he and the foreman examined it, and found nothing but the mittens; he then ordered the foreman to go for an officer - he gave me in charge, and I was taken to the station-house, the porter carrying the portmanteau - when brought to the station-house they examined it, and found the stockings; I knew nothing of their being in theportmanteau - it was exposed to every body in the house, and I and my fellow-servants were not living comfortbly together.
MR. ROBERTSHAW re-examined. I only found the mittens - the officer has not stated where he found the stockings.
Q. Was the box opened before be produced the key to the Policeman? A. I consider not, for the things were particularly smooth, and he desired the Policeman to keep them smooth.

JOHN HOWARD re-examined. I found the stockings at the station-house; they were in the sleeves of one of the prisoner's coats in the portmanteau; I was in the drawing-room all the while that the portmanteau was open - I unlocked it myself; there was no hesitation in bringing it forward while I was there: the portmanteau opens in the middle - his clothes were in the upper division, but the coat was not the first thing: the trousers were on the top of them - I know nothing of the portmanteau being opened before I searched it; the things were smooth, and did not appear to have been meddled with - I locked the box myself, after examining it in the drawing-room, and put the key into my own pocket.
Prisoner. The prosecutor's porter is here, and he knows my fellow-servants were not on good terms with me.

JAMES WHITE
. I am the prosecutor's porter. I believe the prisoner and his fellow-servants were not on good terms - I know nothing of the box being down in the kitchen before he left.

Prisoner. Q. Do not you know it was down in the kitchen all the time? A. I know it was in the passage just as you were leaving, and Mr. Rutherford said, "Whose is that?" the prisoner said, "It is my portmanteau;" that is all I know - this was about ten o'clock at night; I had been out all day, and had not seen it before.

Prisoner. Q. Do not you know that Mr. Rutherford and I had it open in the counting-house, and all the things out, before it went into the drawing-room? A. This is the first I have heard of that - he did not always agree with his fellow-servants; I have lived there about three months - I never knew his box to be left open; I considered him very reserved and close, and not likely to leave his box open, and never knew him leave the key about.

JURY to MR. ROBERTSHAW. Q. Were the stockings kept in a place which the prisoner had access to? A. They were kept in the window, and must have been taken when he undid the nuts of the shutters in the morning; I should certainly have missed them.
GUILTY. Aged 28.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Three Months .

241.
PETER BRADLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of December , 1 looking-glass, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Soloman Worms
.

SOLOMON WORMS. I am a broker , and live in Queen-street, St. Giles'
. On the 11th of December this looking-glass was outside my window, which was not open; I had a lad there to mind the things - an opposite neighbour's lad hallooed out; I ran out, and saw the looking-glass in the road, opposite my door - it was mine; I had seen it safe five minutes before.

JAMES KING
. I am twelve years old, and live with my brother, who is a broker, opposite Mr. Worms'. I was looking across just at dusk, and saw Worms' lad talking to two other boys; the big boy gave Worms' boy a piece of sweet-stuff - I saw the prisoner take the glass off the door, and walk away with it; I ran over and caught him - he then dropped it, and said, "Let me go;" I called to Worms, who came out, took the glass up, and claimed it; I had seen the prisoner before, I did not know who he was.

JOSEPH TINDALL
. I took the prisoner in charge with the glass.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was going down Queen-street to my mother, and bought a halfpenny worth of sweet-stuff; a boy threw the glass into the road - the boy ran after me, and called another man.

GUILTY . Aged 12. -
Transported for Seven Years .

242.
THOMAS WHITE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of December , 1 coach-cover, value 10s.; 1 set of reins, value 5s.; 1 basket, value 1s.; 2 bags, value 1s.; 1 piece of leather, value 1s.; 1 cushion, value 10s.; 2 mats, value 10s.; 1 jacket, value 5s.; 1 waistcoat, value 3s., and 1 towel, value 3d., the goods of
William Frank Fisher
; 1 cap, value 6d., and 1 towel, value 3d., the goods of
James Hartford
.

WILLIAM FRANK FISHER. I live at Thistle-grove, Fulham-road
. I saw the articles stated in the indictment safe in my wash-house, about four o'clock on the 13th of December - it is kept locked, and is surrounded by a wall; we found in the morning an attempt had been made to force the door which enters into a private lane -I found the prisoner in custody, in Kensington watch-house, with some of the articles, in the morning; the coach-house door had been forced open, and the windows of the stables were broken - it had been all safe over night.

JAMES HOLFORD
. I am servant to Mr. Fisher. I saw the coach-house safe at eight o'clock in the evening - every thing was then locked up; I got up next morning at a quarter before seven, and found the coach-house door was broken off - the staple of the lock was drawn; part of a pane of glass was cut out of the stable window, but there was an iron bar inside; the coach-house door was broken open by some strong instrument - I missed a cap and a towel of my own, the other things were master's; I found the prisoner in custody with the whole of them, at six o'clock in the morning - they were in a bag, which had been in the coach-house; the prisoner worked at Little Chelsea about twelve months ago, and I have seen him once since - he said nothing to me at the watch-house.

JAMES McCARTHY
. I am a Policeman. I was coming home at half-past one o'clock at night, and heard somebody at the back of the prosecutor's premises; I stood still till it came close to me, and it turned out to be the prisoner - he heard me coming towards him, and bolted as hard as he could; I followed after him as hard as I could - he passed the stable, and had a bundle on his shoulder; he got over a bedge, and threw the bundle over a fence - I saw no one with him; I got over the fence, leaving the bundle there, and never lost sight of him till I caught him, and brought him back to the bundle, which I sold him tocarry to the station-house, but he would not; I sprang my rattle, and a private watchman came - he carried the bundle to the station; Mr. Fisher and his son came and claimed the property - I found inside the coach-house door another bundle, ready to be carried away.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I had no bundle at all, nor any thing; I deny the charge altogether. I was in distress and out of work.
JAMES McCARTHY. I am sure I saw him throw the bundle over the fence and run away.

GUILTY . Aged 57. -
Transported for Seven Years .
NEW COURT. WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 15.
Third Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

243.
JAMES BOWDEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of December , 11 pairs of stockings, value 10s. , the goods of
Samuel Everingham
.

WILLIAM JACKSON. I am shopman to Mr. Samuel Everingham: he is a hosier , and lives in Oxford-street
. I was at his door about twenty-five minutes past ten o'clock in the morning of the 6th of December: I saw the prisoner looking at the things - I went behind the counter, and in a few minutes I saw something fall at the door; I ran out, and saw the prisoner in about a minute in Noel-street - he had an apron on with something in it; I brought him back to the shop, and called an officer, who opened his apron, and found these eleven pairs of stockings, which are my master's, and had been at the door.

JOHN MC.GILL
. On the 6th of December I was called, and took the prisoner in the shop; I found these eleven pairs of stockings in his apron - I took him to the watch-house, and asked what he meant to do with them; he said some boys in Regent-street said they would give him 6d. a pair, if he could get some.

GUILTY . Aged 13. -
Transported for Seven Years

244.
ALICE DAVIS
and
ANN DAVIS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of October , 35 yards of ribbon, value 20s. , the goods of
William Davies
.

GEORGE HOWELL. I am shopman to Mr. William Davies, a haberdasher of Chiswell-street
. On the 30th of October I saw both the prisoners in my master's shop, about half-past five o'clock; one of them asked to look at some ribbon - I showed them a drawer and a basket of ribbons; they bought two lengths of 1 1/2 yard each, which came to 2s. 2 1/4d., and they paid for them - I saw
Alice Davis
had a handkerchief in her hand, which she put on a piece of ribbon on the counter; she took her handkerchief away, and I missed the ribbon, but I did not see what was done with it - she put her handkerchief on the counter several times, but no more ribbon was missed; I did not see Ann do any thing but talk to the other - I did not hear what was said; I told Mr.
John Davies
, and he went to the door - I showed them some crape handkerchiefs, but they said they did not want any; they were then going out - Mr. John Davies stopped them when they had got about two yards from the counter - he took them into the back shop, and Ann delivered up two half-pieces of ribbon; I did not see them delivered up, but when I went in a young man was measuring them over.

JOHN DAVIES
. I am brother to
William Davies
. In consequence of information from Howell I came into the shop - I waited about the door till the prisoners were going out, and then detained them; I took them to the back shop - they went quietly, but one of them appeared confused when I spoke to them; I did not see Ann do any thing when she came from the counter, I am quite sure of that; I spoke to them, and asked how many pieces of ribbon they had got; Ann held herself down, and I saw she had a handkerchief and a bag in her hand - she gave me this half-piece of ribbon; I then said to Alice, "How many have you got?" she said, "We have got no more, Sir;" I asked them to walk up higher in the warehouse - I again asked Alice, and told her I had seen her several times, and always suspected that she stole ribbons; I felt their pockets, and found nothing, but in about ten minutes I lifted up Ann's cloak, and found this other half-piece under her arm; they were shown to the shopman.

GEORGE HOWELL
. I saw Alice put her handkerchief on one of these, but I cannot swear which - it was one of the same pattern as one of these; I believe I have stated that I could not swear that either of the ribbons produced were what I saw Alice draw off the counter - it was the same pattern. but I cannot swear it is the same price; here is the private mark of the shop on them - when we sell these we sell them with the mark on; I had sold them some ribbon - this is it.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You went from the prisoners to Mr. Davis? A. Yes - I do not believe they had then paid for what they had bought, but I cannot say to a certainty; I did leave them when I went to Mr. Davies, and they were within four yards of the door: Mr. Davies was about twenty-five yards further in - I found the prisoners in the same place when I came back; the door was open, and they might have gone out.
COURT. Q. Do you speak to these ribbons by the marks on them? A. Yes.
JURY. Q. Are you sure you had not sold them these? A. Yes.

JOHN DAVIES
re-examined. Q. Did you say any thing before the Magistrate about Ann stooping down? A. I said they did not stoop at the time they went out.

DAVID WILSON
. I am an officer. I was sent for, and took the prisoner and these two pieces of ribbon - as I went up to them I saw one piece on the counter, and Mr. Davies was in the act of taking the other from Ann: Ann said she had picked them up from the shop floor - I took them to the station.

Cross-examined. Q. Were there many people in the shop? A. Yes, Sir - I should think a score: I think one piece might have fallen on the floor - Mr. Davies heard her say she had picked them up; the prisoners were searched, and two half-crowns and 3s. 6d. were found on them.

Alice Davis
' Defence. I was going to see a relation who was very ill - I saw the ribbons marked up very cheap, which induced me go in and look at them; we bought a yard and a half of one of them - in going out my sister kicked against something; I said, "My love, you have dropped your reticule;" "Have I, my love?" said she - she stooped and picked up one of these ribbons - I thensaw there was another, and I said to the shopman, "Here are some ribbons about the floor;" Mr. Davies then came and accused us of stealing them - he called us young thieves, and said he knew we were so.

GEORGE HOWELL
. I have heard what they have stated - it is not true; they did not stoop till they were going back to the warehouse - they were about one yard from the counter.

COURT to
JOHN DAVIES
. Q. Did you not state to the Magistrate that Ann stooped down, but you laid hold of her before she reached the ground? A. Yes - I did not state that to-day, because I was not asked.

Cross-examined. Q. Did they pay for the ribbon after Howell had called you? A. Yes, and when he took the money I was at the door watching them; I then went to him at the desk, and said, "George, are you sure they have a piece of ribbon?" they could certainly have gone out while he came to me, but they had not then paid for the ribbon.
JURY. Q. Did you ever know any ribbons to be on the floor? A. No.

Alice Davis
. The shopman said the basket was so full he must take some out and put into another basket; he picked some up himself behind the counter.
GEORGE HOWELL. No. I did not.
The prisoners received good characters.

ALICE DAVIS
- GUILTY. Aged 17.

ANN DAVIS
- GUILTY, Aged 13.

Recommended to Mercy by the Jury . -
Confined 1 Month .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

245.
JOSEPH ROEBUCK
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 30th of October , 10 kid skins, value 20s., the goods of
Henry Fownes
and others, well knowing them to have been stolen .
MR. ALLEY conducted the prosecution.

HENRY FOWNES. I am a glove manufacturer , and am in partnership with other persons - we have one place of business in Tavistock-street, and one at Battersea. On the 2nd of October, between four and five dozen of skins in an unmanufactured state, were lost from our premises at Battersea; they are never sold in that state - I went with my brother and two officers to the prisoner's premises, on the 30th of October; we saw the prisoner there.

THOMAS ROBERT FOWNES
. After we had lost these skins, I made great inquiries, and went to the prisoner's house, in Whitechapel
, on the 29th of October - I saw him, and asked if he made gloves to order; he said he did - I asked him to show me some colours of leather; he showed me two drab skins, and one brown one - I purchased one skin, and sent it down that night to Battersea- I received it back the next morning; I and my brother went to the prisoner's with two officers; I saw the prisoner, and asked him where he had bought the skin I had bought of him the day before - he said he did not know any thing about it; I then asked him to show me the two skins I had looked at - he said he did not know any thing about them; I then asked if be had sold them - he said No; I said, "Have you cut them up into gloves?" he said, "I have not, I know nothing at all about them; but if they were here last night, they are here now;" the officers then searched the shop, and in a basket behind the counter, under some waddings, they found some black skins - there were between three and four dozens; my brother selected nine skins, as part of those which had been taken from us - my brother is always at the manufactory; we asked the prisoner to account for them - his answers were evasive; he said he had bought some of a Mr. Bevington, and some of Mr. Savage - he did not name any one else at that time, but at the Police-office, he said he bought them of George Arnold; I do not identify the skins.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. About what size shop is the prisoner's? A. A small shop - he appeared to sell waddings and skins for muffs, but the whole was in a very confused state; when I went in the first time the skins were on the left-hand side, and he produced them openly to me; they were drab, which is a common colour in the trade - my brother's name was not on the skins; a stranger might have bought them innocently.

HENRY FOWNES
. I went with the officer, and found the skins - I picked out nine, which I know to be our property, and was a part of those stolen from us on the 2nd of October - we never sold any in that state.

COURT. Q. What is your opinion respecting the others? A. That they were other persons' property - they were not ours decidedly; the nine selected were all black- our dyers put a private-mark on them, by which I know them.

Cross-examined. Q. Who are your dyers? A. We have several; they do not all make the same mark - they are our own men; they do not dye for other persons - some of them are here; I will not swear they do not dye for other persons - these skins are finished, and were so when we found them; we have sold finished black skins, and dealt very extensively in them, but not in this state - we never sell black skins, unless they are strained, which these are not.

MR. ALLEY. Q. You never sell them in this state? A. No; I can speak decidedly, with respect to the drab skin - that is not strained; they are worth 20s.; the prisoner never was on our premises, nor saw our men.

SAMUEL PRENDERGRASS
. I am an officer. I went to the shop, and found under the counter a basket with the skins in it; out of which Mr. Fownes selected nine - they were covered with wadding.

JOHN DANCE
. I am a dyer employed by the prosecutors. These skins are all my master's property.

JOHN PEDDOR
. I am a dyer to the prosecutors. These are their skins.

GEORGE ARNOLD
. I am a glove-manufacturer. I saw the officer with these skins at the Police-office; I never sold these or any other to the prisoner - I have not seen him these three years.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you know him? A. Yes, I know him well - I know one Mr. Corran to my sorrow; he was in my service.

Prisoner's Defence. A lady came to my shop on the 9th of October, and wished me to make a pair of kid gloves to her size; I had not got a skin which would do, and on the 10th I set off at seven o'clock in the morning to go to Mr. Arnold's to buy a coloured skin for the purpose of making a pair of gloves, to be ready by the Monday - when I got to Oxford-street I had a wish to go andsee the park, but went into a public-house, and had a glass of gin and water - when I had been there some time, who should come in but a young person named Insel - we were rather surprised to see each other, and I said, "What brings you here?" he said, "I and King have been to
George Arnold
's with a parcel;" I said, "Where is he? I want to see him;" we came out, I left him, and went to Arnold's - I purchased six coloured skins and twelve black ones of him - the six coloured I gave 13s. 9d. for, and the black ones 1l. 2s. 6d. - I paid him 13s. 9d. for the coloured skins, not intending to buy any black, as I had some at home; but he wished me to take them, and I was to pay him next time I went to the West-end; when I was at the office Arnold denied that Insel or King had been at his house.

JURY to GEORGE ARNOLD. Q. Did you see the prisoner on the day mentioned? A. I have not seen him these three years; there is no truth in what he has stated- a young man brought a parcel one Sunday morning in October to go in my parcel to Torrington - I do not know what it contained; I do not know the young man's name.

GUILTY . Aged 29. -
Transported for Seven Years .

246.
MARY BARRET
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of December , 1 sheet, value 3s. , the goods of
Robert Fox
.

CHARLES JAMES FOX
. I am the brother of
Robert Fox
- he keeps the Star, in Old Gravel-lane
; this sheet hung out to dry, and I saw the prisoner, on the 11th of December, come down the passage, take it off the line, and walk away with it - I pursued, and took her with it, folded up under her cloak - this is it.

GUILTY . Aged 55. -
Confined Two Years .

247.
THOMAS BETTS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of December , 1 pair of trousers, value 1s.; 1 Guernsey frock, value 1s.; 1 plane, value 1s.; 2 books, value 1s.; 10 yards of ribbon, value 1s., and 1 shell, value 1s. , the goods of
Joseph Titford
.

JOSEPH TITFORD
. This is my property, and was in my chest on board the ship Roslyn, in the West India-dock
- I had not seen the prisoner on board that ship; he did not belong to it - I missed this property on the 2nd of December, and I saw it found on the prisoner at the Police-office; he was a stranger to me.

JOHN BISHOP
. I am an officer. I stopped the prisoner coming out of the dock with these things; I found on him one plane, two printed books, ten yards of ribbon, and a shirt, wrapped up in a pair of trousers - he said they had been given him by a lad on board the Roslyn; I took him there, and found the ship-keeper and a boy - they said he had been sent there, and was desired to go on shore again- I took him to the office, the prosecutor appeared, and identified the property.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY. Aged 16. -
Judgment Respited
.

248.
MARY ANN BLOUNT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of December , 7lbs. weight, of bacon, value 3s. , the goods of
Charles Clark
.

JANE CLARK
. I am the wife of
Charles Clark
- we keep a chandler's-shop , in Marylebone
. On the 9th of December the prisoner came in to sell a 7lbs. weight; I would not buy it, and then she took this bacon from a board by the door - my husband went, and took her six doors off with the bacon.

GUILTY . Aged 36. -
Transported for Seven Years .

249.
JOHN CLARK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of December , 1 pair of trousers, value 3s., the goods of
Henry Gardner
; 1 case of mathematical instruments, value 6d., the goods of
James Stride
; and 1 saw, value 2s., the goods of
George Joad
and others .

HENRY GARDNER
. I am a mariner . This pair of trousers are mine, and were taken from the steerage of the Jane and Catherine, in the West India-docks
- the constable brought them to me on board the ship, and I knew them to be mine - I know nothing of the prisoner.

ROBERT TAYLOR
. I am a watchman.
John George
stopped the prisoner, and brought him to me at the West India Export-dock - I asked how he came in possession of the trousers - he said he took them from on board the Jane and Catherine, and the case of mathematical instruments likewise - this saw, he said, he found by the side of some logs of timber; he is a labouring man, but does not belong to the dock.

GUILTY . Aged 27. -
Confined Six Months .

250.
GEORGE COATS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of December , 4 pairs of shoes, value 10s. , the goods of
Joseph Johnson
.

JAMES ODWELL. I am a shopman to Mr.
Joseph Johnson
, of Tottenham-court-road
. I saw a hand take hold of the shoes - I ran from the further end of the shop, and took the prisoner with the shoes in his possession - I took him by the collar; these are the shoes.

GUILTY . Aged 14. -
Whipped and Discharged.

251.
GEORGE CHAPMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of December , 2 bushels of onions, value 10s., and 1 sack, value 6d. , the goods of
Charles Richardson
.

CHARLES RICHARDSON. I am a market-gardener , and live at Isleworth
. I lost these onions from a shed belonging to my house, on Friday last - they had been transferred from where I had left them, into a hay-loft, put into a sack, and partly concealed under hay-bands and other litter; the prisoner was my carter, and was going to town the same evening with me.

HANNAH SMITH
. I am servant to Mr. Richardson. A little before one o'clock on Friday, I saw the prisoner put a prop against the hay-loft door, which I never saw before - I told my master I thought there was something wrong in the loft; I had seen the prisoner loading onions on the cart at five o'clock in the evening.

CHARLES RICHARDSON
. I had the prisoner stopped with his cart, when he had got five hundred yards from my house, and I pretended I wanted a sovereign changed- I then found these onions.

Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. These onions had been transferred from one part to another? A. Yes - he was employed to carry onions for sale, but he never took any to sell without my direction; I have generally been on the premises when he has loaded his cart - I have sometimes been in London, and he has brought the cart to me, but I prepare my own goods formarket in a particular manner, and when they have been loaded he takes them - the shed was at the back of my premises.

COURT. Q. You have no doubt the onions were yours? A. No; I saw them at one o'clock, and saw them on the cart at five, in the same sack - the prisoner had 12s. a week, and 1s. a night when he went to market.
Prisoner's Defence. I do not know how they came on the cart.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .

252.
ELIZABETH CRATTY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of November , 1 shawl, value 10s., the goods of
Sarah Butler
, her mistress ; to which she pleaded.

GUILTY . -
Confined Three Months .

253.
ISABELLA CLARK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of December , 1 handkerchief, value 5s. , the goods of
Henry Woods
.
ELIZABETH WOODS. I am the wife of Henry Woods, and am a laundress. I took a handkerchief like this out of a basket in my own room - the prisoner was washing for me.

GEORGE ADNAM
. I am a pawnbroker. The prisoner pawned a handkerchief like this with me on the 2nd of December, and redeemed it on the 3rd.
NOT GUILTY .

254.
JOHN CHAMPHIN
and
CHARLES BARNET
were indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of November , 1 live tame rabbit, price 2s. , the property of
Anthony Rule
.

ANTHONY RULE
. I live at Tottenham
. I lost a rabbit on the 12th of November - I had seen it safe at seven o'clock that evening, near my stable door in the hutch, which was fixed against the stable wall - the hutch door was shut and buttoned; I came home about eight o'clock, and missed it - I saw it on the 13th, hanging at Mr. Garner's door. a grocer and cheesemonger; I knew it was mine - the prisoners are labourers, and live a little way from me.

JOSEPH STACE
. I live with Mr. Garner. About a quarter past eight o'clock, on the evening of the 12th of November, champhin came to his shop, and asked 20d. for this rabbit - I took it to Mr. Garner, who told me to offer him 1s. 4d.; he went out and came in again, and said he would take 1s. 6d., and we gave it him.

Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. Did you know him? A. Yes; I did not see the other boy - Champhin lives at Tottenham; I have bought rabbits of him be-- I have been at his house; this was such a rabbit as I had not seen before.

JOHN FOWLER
. I am a constable. I saw Barnet on the 13th of November, up the road, with his father's cart- he ran across the road; I said, "You were going to run away;" he said, "No, I was going to speak to
Anthony Rule
about the rabbit that Champhin and I found last night, in the lane;" I found nine-pence on him, which he said was half the money they got for it.

ANTHONY RULE
. This is the skin of the rabbit - my stable is in the corner of my yard; there is a skittle-ground adjoining it; there is but a slight fence - if the rabbit got out of the hutch it might get out of the ground: I had had it five weeks.
NOT GUILTY .

255.
JAMES EVES
and
WILLIAM GOUGH
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of December , 1 watch, value 2l.; 1 watch-chain, value 1s.; 3 watch-keys, value 3s.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s.; 1 snuff-box, value 6d.; 1 brooch, value 10s.; 2 gold pins, value 6s.; 12 penny-pieces, and 10 halfpence , the property of
Charles Loxton
.

CHARLES LOXTON. I am a toll-collector . in Cannon-street-road
. Eves had been with me as a toll-collector -Gough worked at the docks , and he knew the toll-house; on the night of the 5th of December I was in my toll-house; and fell asleep about eleven o'clock - I had my coat on, and the articles stated were about me; the brooch and the pins were in the snuff-box, and the money was over the fire-place - there is a back-door, which was latched but not bolted; I was awoke by the Policeman - I then missed the articles, and reported the circumstance to another officer, and as we were returning, we overtook the officer bringing the prisoners to the watch-house - they were searched, and a key was found on Eves; I did not hear Gough say a word - this is the key, but I do not know that I can swear positively to it; there are a great many alike.

COURT. Q. Did you ever swear that "The key produced is the same pattern with that in my snuff-box, it had lost its ring, and I have no doubt it is the same?" A. Yes, I have no doubt, but I should not like to swear to it without I was positively certain - it has very much the appearance of it, but I would not swear it is the key.

JOHN EAGLES
. I am a Police-officer. About ten minutes before twelve o'clock, I was at the turnpick-gate, and saw the two prisoner come out of the toll-house - an officer asked me it it was all right; I said, yes - it was Eves' brother, and knowing him, I had no suspicion of him; he was very much in liquor, and could scarcely stand - I then went up my beat, returned, and saw the door open; I went and said to the prosecutor, "Charles, you will lose your shirt" - I saw the back door was open; he then looked and missed his property - we went to several places, and on coming back found the prisoners in custody; they were taken to the watch-house, and Eves threw this key, two or three little bits of paper, 2d. and a bad shilling on the table; he caught up the key again to put it into his pocket; the prosecutor said, "Put that down, it is mine."
Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. Had the backdoor been fastened? A. I do not know; the front door was open eight or ten inches.

PETER COSTELLE
. I am an officer. I was on duty ten minutes or a quarter of an hour before eleven o'clock, and saw the two prisoners coming along the Commercial-road arm-in-arm and seriously talking together; I stood on one side to try to hear what they said - when they came up to me, they silenced their discourse, and crossed to another beat; I saw no more of them till about twelve o'clock, when I saw Gough on the foot-path at the end of the Cannon-street-road - I walked by him, returned, and said, "It is a cold night;" he said, "Yes; will you have a drop of gin?""No, thank you," said I - I then saw Eves on the other side, talking to some girl; Gough said, "I will take good care he shall not go with that girl;" and he went and spoke to him - Eves then left the girl, and they went on together; I followed them to a public-house door, they knocked, but the publican refused to draw any more liquor - I then went and said, I wished him to open thedoor; we went in, and the prisoner asked what I would take - I said, "A small glass of rum;" and they had a pint of porter and some gin - Eves said to Gough, "You must pay for this;" Gough put his hand in his pocket and pulled out a wooden box, he took something out of it, and put it into his right-hand trousers pocket - he shut the box again, and Eves laid down 9 1/2d.; the publican said there was another halfpenny wanted - Gough paid the other half-penny, and handed the box to Eves; Eves said, "I shall not be done, put them back again;" Gough then put a brooch and a pin into the box - It was a twisted pin as far as the centre part of it, and the brooch had a kind of stone in it; they were in a box-wood coloured snuff-box, rather brown, and a little the worse for wear - Eves again said, "I shall not be done, there is some more;" Gough then put his hand into his pocket, took out a watch-key, put that into the box, and Eves had the box - I am sure there was a watch-key, pin, and brooch, in the box; but this is not the key, I did not see this key at all; that was a long smooth key - I afterwards took them, and when we were at the watch-house, I was ordered to search Eves, he said he would not be searched - he threw this key on the table and took it up again; the prosecutor said, "That is my property, I will swear to it;" Eves twice attempted to run away from me.

Cross-examined. Q. How long was it before you apprehended them? A. I suppose three quarters of an hour - we went to the Commercial-road, and they went, away; I merely went to the public-house for information not for the sake of the rum - I would drink vinegar or turpentine for information; they were not long in my company - there was no attempt at concealment; I had not known them before - the toll-house is not on my beat; Eves was much the worse for liquor.

CHARLES LOXTON
. My snuff-box was a dark brown, something of a box-wood colour - it contained two pins, a brooch, and two keys; the brooch was an old fashioned one, with three letters on it - this is very much like one of the keys; I had kept it in the box because it had lost its ring.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe you were on the most friendly terms with Eves? A. Yes; his brother is one of the superintendents of the trust, and it would have been his duty to be there at half-past five or six o'clock the next morning - I went to sleep about eleven, and was awoke about ten minutes before twelve; this robbery must have been between eleven and twelve - I have seen many other keys like this, and I will not swear to this; I have seen no other property - it was Sunday night, and the shops were not open.
JURY. Q. Have you seen many such keys without a ring? A. No.

Eves' Defence. I know nothing of the business; the Policeman is quite mistaken in saying it was a wooden box- it was a tin tobacco-box, and the articles in it were the brooch out of my shirt, the ring off my finger, and the key, which I put into the box for safety.

ROBERT HENRY CLEET
. I am a master mariner, and live at No. 5, Johnson-street, Old Gravel-lane. On Sunday night, the 5th of December, I saw the two prisoners going into Mr. Ireland's, at the Crown and Dolphin, at the corner of Cannon-street-road. soon after ten o'clock - they sat drinking in the tap-room, and I went into the bar, which commands a view of the two entrances; I was there till near twelve o'clock, and during that time I never saw Eves go out till he went out for good, which was between a quarter to twelve and twelve - I saw Gough go out twice during the time; he was absent but a short time - I saw him come in again each time; perhaps he was out about five minutes - the reason they left was, Mr. Ireland was desirous of getting rid of them. as Eves was very much in liquor - he could scarcely stand; he stood twenty minutes or half an hour at the bar - I am quite positive Eves did not go out.
NOT GUILTY .

256.
ROBERT FITKIN
,
WILLIAM TUSTON
, and
JOHN GRIMES
were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of November , 3 books, value 9s. , the goods of
Lorenzo Lacklan
.

JOSEPH WILKINS
. I am an officer. On Saturday evening, the 27th of November, I saw the prisoners standing near the White Horse, where they generally assemble together: they had some books, and knowing there were some stolen, I watched them, and saw them taking them about for sale; I got a man to assist me, and I went and took two books from Fitkin, and while I was taking a third book from Tuston's hat. Fitkin ran away - I pursued and took him in the top room of a house - I then went to Tuston's house, who came with me very willingly; Grimes was the first who had offered the books for sale - I afterwards found the prosecutor in Scotland-yard.
Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. What did Grimes and Tuston do? A. Both ran away - Tuston said, he received them of a man in Orchard-street, in a long white coat.

LORENZO LACKLAN. I live in Scotland-yard
. These books are mine - I missed them on the Monday morning, but they were taken on the Saturday.
Cross-examined. Q. Where did you keep them? A. Outside the window; I am sure they were there between three and four on Saturday.

ANN SUMMERS
. On that Saturday Grimes brought me three books, and asked me to buy them - I said I would not; the other two prisoners were with him.

Grime's Defence. I was going through Orchard-street- I met these two young men, who said, "We have been and bought some books - I wish you would ask Mrs. Minchington, where Summers lives, and what is the value of them;" I went to ask, and she called out that she did not deal in books; we went out, and Summers came after us, and said her mistress would buy them - we showed them to her, but she said she would not.
Fitkin's Defence. I was offered the two English books for 2s. 6d., and I gave 2s. and some halfpence for them.
The prisoners received good characters.

FITKIN -
GUILTY . Aged 20.

TUSTON -
GUILTY . Aged 19.

GRIMES -
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Confined One Month in the House of Correction .

257.
THOMAS GOOLD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of November , 3 reams of paper, value 4l. the goods of
Moses Valentine
.

MOSES VALENTINE
. I am a fancy-card paper-maker , and live in Allerton-street, Hoxton
. I have seen the prisoner about town for the last two or three years - he had applied to me for employment: I gave him a job or two - on the 20th of November he came and said he had an order from a gentleman in Cheapside for two reams of pink paper; I told him I had no objection to complete the order for him, but I could not afford to allow him any profit - he said, "I don't want profit, I only want journeyman's wages;" I then agreed to let him have it - he came on the following Monday, I was out; he came on the Tuesday, and I got it completed by the Thursday evening; I was out, my wife would not allow him to take it; he came the next day - he said, "Valentine, are you ready to take this paper to Mr. Wilson's;" I said "Yes, I will go in a moment with you;" I had expected from what he said, that Mr. Wilson would pay me - we went on to Cheapside, he went into the house, left the paper, came out and said to me, "We must wait for Mr. Wilson for an hour;" I said, "Well, I have no objection, suppose we go to a coffee-shop;" he said, "No, I want to go to Fetter-lane, and by the time we come back, the hour will he up;" we went there, he went into a shop, came out and said, "I have to wait twenty minutes," I said, "I will wait no more in the street," I went to a coffee shop, and paid for breakfast for us both; he then said he had a pain in his bowels, he got up as if to go to the bar, but went away, and I saw no more of him till I found him on the Wednesday after at Gravesend.

THOMAS WILSON
. My father keeps a shop in Cheapside. On the 26th of November, the prisoner came, left three parcels tied up, and inquired for my father - I said he would be in in about an hour; he came in about an hour, and took the parcels away - we had given no order for paper.

THOMAS VANN
. I went with the prosecutor, and took the prisoner at Gravesend, on the 1st of December - he said the paper was not all sold, half of it was at his lodging- I went and found half of it - this is it.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he considered he had purchased the paper of the prosecutor.
GUILTY. Aged 27.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined One Month .

258.
ELIZABETH GREEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of December , 1 sheet, value 5s., and 1 bracelet, value 5s. , the goods of
Elizabeth Franklin
.

ELIZABETH FRANKLIN. I live in New Tethill-street
. The prisoner lodged in another room in the same house, for six months - I lost this property.

JAMES DEEDY
. I am in the employ of Mr. Jones, a pawnbroker. I have a sheet, brought by Lawbridge, on the 6th of December, but we had received information, and gave her into custody.

MARY LOWBRIDGE
. I am an unfortunate girl. I have known the prisoner some time - she gave me this sheet, and told me to pawn it; she said it belonged to herself- I was detained; I met her at the King's Head, in Orchard-street - she works at her needle; I never was at the prosecutor's.

WILLIAM CLIFTON
. I am an officer. I was sent for, and went to the prosecutrix, to ascertain how she had been robbed - I found the window and door fast; I went and got a search warrant - while I was there the pawnbroker's young man came with Lowbridge, and the sheet; I then went and searched the prisoner's lodging, and in the bed I found this bracelet - the key of the prisoner's room door unlocks the prosecutor's door as easy as the key that belongs to it.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I went to another person to ask her to lend me 2s. - she said she had no money, but gave me the sheet to raise the money.

HONOR GREAVE
. I lodge at the same house, and have worked at the army-work for twenty-two years. The prisoner never asked me such a thing, and I never gave her the sheet.

GUILTY . Aged 30. -
Transported for Seven Years .

259.
JOHN HANSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of November , 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Thomas Ben Sowerby
.

JOHN MOXON. I am in the employ of
Thomas Ben Sowerby
, a pawnbroker . On the 12th of November a person came in and told me something; I went out, and saw the prisoner and another boy running on the opposite side - I followed them, and saw them join six others; they spoke a few words, and then ran on - I followed the prisoner; he threw a handkerchief out of his pocket - I took it up, and went and took the prisoner; this is the handkerchief - it is my master's.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that hearing an alarm he ran with others, but was innocent.
Two witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 14.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury .
Whipped and Discharged.

260.
MARY HANDLIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of December , 1 silver spoon, value 2s. , the goods of
Edward John Howard
.

CHARLES HOLT
. I am in the service of Mr.
Edward John Howard
, a solicitor , who lives in Duke-street, St. James'
. The prisoner had lived as cook in his family, but had left it - on the 9th of December she called, and said she had seen my master in the morning, and he had appointed to meet her at three o'clock; I said my master was not then at home, and she had better go into the office, as we are not allowed to let any one remain in the kitchen - one of the clerks then knocked at the door; I went and let him in, and when I returned to the kitchen the prisoner was just going out; I missed a tea-spoon - I took the prisoner's arm, said she must have it, and desired her to give it up without more words - she gave it from her bosom or her pocket; this is it.
Prisoner's Defence. His wife had got the situation that I held, and he thought I wanted to get back again - that is the reason he says this.

GUILTY. Aged 21. -
Judgment Respited
.

261.
JOHN HARMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of December , 1 pair of boots, value 5s. , the goods of
William Pinson
.

EDWARD READER
. I live in Charlotte-street, and am a medical-man - the prosecutor lives next door to me. -On Thursday morning last I saw the prisoner take a pair of boots from his window, and walk away; I went out, stopped him, and took them both from him; he did not go into the shop, but stood against the window.

WILLIAM PRIMROSE
. I am a shoemaker. I was at home at the time, but did not see these boots taken - they are mine.
Prisoner. It is my first offence.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Confined One Month .

262.
ELIZABETH HOLLYER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of November , 3 yards of cotton, value 3s.; 1 tea-cup, value 6d.; 1 hat, value 6d.; 25 herrings, value 9d.; 1 blanket, value 10s.; 1 pair of boots, value 6s.; 1 cloak, value 4s., and 1 key, value 6d. , the goods of
Ann Harris
.

ANN HARRIS. I am a widow , and go out charing. I was at the Castle, in Chapel-street, Westminster
, on Saturday fortnight; I had a bundle, containing all the articles stated, except the cloak and boots, which I had on - I saw the prisoner there; I asked the landlord to take care of my bundle, which he refused - I do not think I went to sleep, but I dozed; I had had more than I am used to - the prisoner said I should go to her room till I recovered myself, and we went together; the waiter at the public-house carried the bundle - the prisoner's sister went with us, and the prisoner and she kept me while they took what I had, and then turned me out of the room - I did not see them take the articles, but I can swear they were in my bundle when I went into the public-house, and the waiter can swear that he took them to the room; I also missed my cloak and my boots off my feet - I did not miss them till I got home; I was drunk - some of the things were found in the prisoner's room.

JOSEPH WILKINS
. I am waiter at the public-house. - The prosecutrix came there very tipsy, and asked for a quartern of gin; my master would not serve her - she sat down, and was going to sleep; my master told me to take her out- I set her against the shutters, and she fell down - the prisoner and her sister came and said I might take her to their house, and she should remain till she recovered; I took her to a lodging, but I do not know whose it was; she then lost her things, and came to my master's house- I took the other woman, whose name was Richardson.

JOSEPH WILKINS. I am a Policeman. About half-past seven o'clock on the Sunday morning, I was on duty, and the prosecutrix said she had been robbed - I asked her of what, and she told me; the prisoner was present, and said she knew nothing of the prosecutrix; she said she lived no where, and had no key, but I knew where she lived, and the waiter said that was the room he took them to - this is the cap, handkerchief, and part of the property which I found there; I took the other woman, but nothing was found on her- when we went to the watch-house, she gave her sister the key.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I never saw the woman before - the waiter took her home on his back.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Seven Years .

263.
THOMAS PLUMB
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of December , 1 handkerchief, value 2s. , the goods of
William Clayton
.

WILLIAM CLAYTON. I am a carpenter . I was in Marylebone-street
on the 10th of December, at half-past eight o'clock - Harris spoke to me; I then felt and missed my handkerchief - I saw the prisoner, and took him; he dropped it, but I did not see him - I saw it first behind him: this is it.

GEORGE HARRIS
. I am an upholsterer. I was in Marylebone-street - I saw the prosecutor there; the prisoner and another person went up to him - the prisoner took up his coat with one hand, and took out his handkerchief - I told the gentleman, and he went back with me to the prisoner, who stood in the road: I said, "That is the one who picked your pocket;" I had seen him put the handkerchief into his outside pocket - Mr. Clayton took hold of him; he took him along, and I saw the prisoner put his hand into his pocket, take out the handkerchief, and throw it into a passage; I gave it to the Policeman.

GEORGE STONE
. I took the prisoner and have the handkerchief.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I throw myself on the mercy of the Court.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Confined Three Months .

264.
JOHN HILT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of December , 4 cheeses, value 20s., the goods of
Richard Cass
and another .
MR. CHURCHILL conducted the prosecution.

JOHN SULLIVAN
. I am a Police-constable. On the 7th of December, I saw the prisoner, and two others, a little before seven o'clock in the evening, on the Newington road
, about two hundred yards from Hackney new church - they were following a waggon; I saw the prisoner go two or three times, and take something out of the tail of it, but it was dark, and I could not see what it was; he, however put it through the rails of Hackney church - I went up and seized him; he struggled very hard, and kicked me two or three times in the I got assistance and secured him, but while I was doing that his companions took away the parcel. whatever it was.

Cross-examined by MR. BALL. Q. Was it not dark. A. Yes - I can swear to the person of the prisoner; I was, perhaps, two hundred yards from him - I had noticed him when I passed him; I was opposite him when he took the parcel, and I seized him when he dropped it; the cheeses were open when they were found.
Re-examined. Q. When you were by the waggon you were near enough to see him? A. Yes.

THOMAS JAMES PARKER
. I am a broker. I was in the road, and saw the prisoner with two others - I saw him go and take something out of the waggon, then cross, and put it within the rails of the church - I assisted to secure the prisoner with Sullivan; I saw a man, in a white jacket, go and take what the prisoner had deposited, and he escaped, and so did the third man; the prisoner resisted very much.
Cross-examined. Q. What distance were you? A. About fifty yards - I can swear to his person.

WILLIAM BENNET WEBSTER
. I was in the road, a little distance from the White Hart - Mr. Parker told me a a Policeman had a man, and I came up and secured the prisoner.
JURY. Q. Were there gas-lights on the road? A. Yes.

JOHN CREAMER
. I am an officer. I was on duty on the morning of the 8th of December, about twenty minutes before eight o'clock - I went to an uninhabited house, a hundred yards from West-Hackney church; I found these three cheeses, placed by the side of each other, against the wall.

THOMAS PRATT
. I am a labourer. On the 7th of December I assisted in loading some cheeses into Mr. Cass' waggon, in Whitechapel - I stood by the horses, and saw the cheeses put in; they were single Gloucester, like these - I went with the waggon, and was in the road when this took place - what the witnesses have sworn to is true.
Cross-examined. Q. Are not these very common cheses? A. I do not know.

THOMAS JENNINGS
. I am a carter, in the employ of Messrs. Cass. I drove the waggon on the 7th, went to Whitechapel, and took in sixty cheeses - I tied them down in the waggon; I did not observe any thing on the cheeses - I went to the station-house; I said to the prisoner, "You have been robbing my waggon of three cheeses;" I made him no threat or promise, but I understood him to answer, "I meant to have had a dozen."
COURT. Q. Soon after the waggon was robbed, you stopped? A. Yes, and ran up the road - when they took the prisoner I missed three cheeses from my waggon.

Cross-examined. Q. How were the cheeses removed? A. Three of them were pulled up, the tilt torn up, and the rope cut - I have been a fortnight in the employ of George and Richard Cass; they are partners - I believe the cheeses are the property of Richard Cass, but the waggon belongs to
George Cass
; he employs me - it is his team; the rope was cut.

WILLIAM BEAMAND
. I am in the employ of Harbin and Larkin, in Whitechapel. I assisted in loading Cass' waggon with sixty Gloucester cheeses - I should know them again; this is one of them - it is marked H.4.; no other cheeses of that mark were sent out of our warehouse- we had but one hundred and twenty, and sixty of them are in our warehouse now; it was Cass' waggon.
Cross-examined. Q. Is not H.4. your general mark on all cheeses? A. It is of that dairy - I can only swear that Mr. Cass bought the whole of that dairy.
JOHN SULLIVAN. I searched the prisoner, but found no knife on him.

Prisoner's Defence. I had been and received 2l.; I drank some 6d. ale, and got tipsy - in going home this man came and took hold of me; he said he wanted me, but would not say for what - we fell in the road, and he said to the waggoner, "You stop the waggon;" he went to his waggon and said he missed for cheeses, the tilt was open, and the rope cut - the serjeant said to the Police-officer, "You must try and convict this man."
JOHN SULLIVAN. There is a reward on conviction, but nothing was said about that.

GUILTY . Aged 27. -
Transported for Seven Years .
Fifth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

265.
JOHN WAPSHERE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of December , 1 bag, value 1d.; 1 crown; 40 half-crowns, 140 shillings, and 38 sixpences , the property of
Alfred Coy Hows
.

ALFRED COY HOWS
. I live in High-street, Shadwell
. On the 7th of December, about ten o'clock in the morning, I had 13l. 4s. in silver in a bag - there was one crown-piece, upwards of twenty half-crowns, more than one hundred shillings, and more than twenty sixpences - I gave the bag to my lad to take to a place where I generally send my silver - he put it at the furthest end of the counter, from the door; I saw the prisoner about ten o'clock that morning - he came immediately the lad had gone down stairs; he asked for 1lb. of sausages - I served him with them; he gave me 1s., and I put 8d. in copper, which was the change, into the meat scale, but he did not take it up - he was at that time standing within reach of the bag- he left the shop without his change; a woman came in before he left - she stood about three yards from where the bag of silver was; the lad came into the shop while she was there, and the bag of silver was missed; I ran out to look for the man, and when I returned, the woman was still there, and they said had been there all the time - no other person but the prisoner and the woman came into the shop after the bag of money was put down till it was missed - I could not find the man.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. I believe you found the man afterwards by his coming to your shop to ask you if you accused him of taking any property of yours? A. Yes, he came with another person, and I charged him with it - he asked if I had any charge against him; I gave him in charge - he was let go, and came of his own accord to the office next day, but I understood there was some guarantee for his appearing; the woman was not searched - another man surrendered; I did not describe him as a tall man - I did not say so to Mr. Lamonte; the prisoner said he worked at the engine, at the London-docks - I went there, and Heatley was taken, as he worked at the engine.

EDWARD HEALE
. I am in the prosecutor's service. On the 7th of December he gave me a bag of money - I laid it on the end of the counter; there was a scale about a foot from it - there was no one there but my master; I went into the cellar for a piece of beef - I returned in five minutes: my master told me to take the bag, and it was gone - there was only one woman in the shop, two or three yards from where the bag had been; my master went out, and the woman remained till he returned. On the evening of the 8th of December the prisoner came to the shop, said he had heard that master had been robbed, and that he was the man who had been in the shop at the time; I told him my master was not at home, but he would be in half an hour - he went out, and returned at that time.
Cross-examined. Q. This was after your master had been making inquiries at the London-docks? A. Yes, and a man named Heatley had surrendered.

ALFRED COY HOWS
. The prisoner came to me on the evening of the 8th, and I said, "You are the man who I suspect has robbed me;" I reminded him about his change - he said he had taken up a sixpence and three halfpence, but I had no sixpence, for I had the minute before, put every bit of silver I had into the bag; I am positive his change was in copper.
Cross-examined. Q. Was this after he had been withyour lad? A. Yes - I had not left out a sixpence; I had just enough to make up the even money - I have never seen the bag or silver since.

JAMES FOGG
. I am a Police-officer. On the 10th of December, I went with Deverell to the prisoner's house, in William-street - I saw the prisoner's wife there, and I found in a drawer, a new gown of Norwich crape; a new table-cloth, a piece of linen, and two silver spoons, under the bed; the table-cloth was not made, and a new jacket and trousers which had not been worn - I went to the prisoner and told him his wife said he had taken these things out of pawn, and they appeared to be tarnished - he said they had been out; I asked him where, but he would not tell me - he said he supposed his wife had told me; he said he had paid his rent that day.
Cross-examined. Q. Was he in custody when you went to his house? A. Yes.

WILLIAM BIDDULPH
. I am a slop-seller. Some months ago the prisoner ordered a frock and a pair of trousers at my shop - they were made in about a fortnight, but he did not call for about a month, and he said he would not take them then, he would call soon; on Tuesday, the 7th of December, he came in the morning, and requested to have 2s. back, of 4s. which he had left as earnest - I let him have the 2s., and in the evening he came again and paid me 12s., which was the balance that was due to me; that was about seven o'clock in the evening, and he had called in the morning between nine and eleven.

Cross-examined. Q. You will not swear it might not have been eleven o'clock? A. I will not swear one way or the other - I had to go out of town, and to be in Oxford-street at twelve o'clock; I started about eleven from home - I know he called before eleven.

JOHN DEVERELL
. I am headborough of Shadwell. On the 8th of December I took the prisoner, in the prosecutor's shop - the prosecutor charged him with stealing the bag; I took him to the watch-house - when we were there, he said he had taken the 6d. and 1 1/2d.; I put some questions about the pawnbroker, which he declined to answer.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe you found him working at the docks? A. Yes, occasionally - I was loath to lock him up, and I left him with a friend or two while I went to make further inquiries - I let him go that night, and he came to the office next day of his own accord; before we parted that night I took a share of a pot of porter, and I believe there was a quartern of gin between six of us - Mr. Lamonte was present; the prisoner said Mr. Hows had given him trouble enough, and if he did not pay for it he would - I let him out because I had been to Mr. Hows, and he had received information that Samuel Heatley was the person who had committed the robbery: I knew where to find him, but Mr. Hows then came and said he was not the man, it was the prisoner he thought; we then parted- I went to the prisoner's house, and his wife said he had been to the shop, and I advised Mr. Hows not to press the charge - I then went to the public-house where the prisoner and his friends were, and I said, if he and his friends would answer in the sum of 20l. I would let him go; I took no regular bail - he came and delivered himself up the next morning; I ascertained that he was well known.

JAMES FOGG
. I saw this examination, written by the clerk, and signed by the magistrate, Captain Richbell . - read.

"On the Tuesday morning in question I went into Mr. How's shop; before that I took home a pair of shoes and a boot to Mr. Dowding, and Dowding paid me 1s. 6d.; I asked for 1 lb. of sausages, no one was in the shop when I went in - Hows was in the back-place, with a pen counting up a book or something- he had a great many halfpence on the counter counted up, and I said to him, "Mr. Hows, how easy I could have a sweep of these in my hat;" Mr. Hows said he was not mistrustful that any one would take them - he put the sausages in the scale, and they were thin ones; he weighed them, and I gave him 1s.; while he was giving me the change a woman came in and began speaking to Mr. Hows - I took my change up and tied the sausages in a handkerchief; there were three pieces of copper with the sixpence - I went from there to the London-dock with the sausages in my hat - I went home, and my wife and I had the sausages' and went to work till half-past twelve o'clock at night; I had not 6d, to get my breakfast when I went out in the morning; the Norwich crape my wife bought at Mr. Hunt's at Shoreditch - he is a tally-man; it might be two years ago. As for the linen it belongs to Mrs. Smith (my wife's sister) - the other piece of linen my wife bought one day this week, I think; the other gown piece was brought while my wife was from home yesterday morning, about nine o'clock, and left with me for my wife to make; I never saw the person who brought it before - she left no name; my wife bought the table-cloths yesterday or the day before - I gave her two sovereigus the day before yesterday; I lost a sovereign out of my pocket yesterday - I sold a Scotch cap and a pair of boots for 1l. 10s. on Tuesday, and I sold some other things. On Tuesday morning last I went and fetched the jacket and trousers from a clothes-shop opposite Gould's-hill - he measured me for them three or four months ago, and I paid him 4s. off, and on Tuesday morning I asked him to let me have 2s. off the 4s., and he did so - when I had sold the things I have mentioned I went and paid him for the the jacket and trousers; I paid him 12s. - his name is Dowditch, or some such name; he knows my name, and has it in his book.
JOHN WAPSHERE
."
Taken before me on the 9th of Dec, 1830. T. Richbell.

Prisoner's Defence. I gave an account at the Police-office who the things belonged to - my wife is a dress-maker; the officer might have found a dozen dresses - the officer had a receipt of the Norwich crape, which my wife gave him off the file.

JAMES FOGG
. I had it, but I do not know that I brought it here; it was merely the bill - I put it in the drawer at the office; I went to Mr. Hunt's, and found it was all right - she had bought it there.
COURT. Q. On what day did you ascertain that it had been bought? A. On the Thursday I went to his house; it had been bought eighteen months ago, at a linen-draper's, in Shoreditch.
NOT GUILTY .

266.
ROBERT HEWITT
and
JAMES HEWITT
were indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 11th of February , 1 pair of hames, value 10s., the goods of
Thomas Pickford
and others, well knowing them to have been stolen .

JOSEPH HAYWARD
. I am in the employ of
Thomas Pickford
, and Co. They lost some harness about nine months ago, and some since, from the City-road wharf - I saw a pair of their hames on a horse belonging to theprisoners, in a street close to their wharf, on the 29th of November - I know it belonged to the prisoners, because they came and took the horse, and gave up the hames to me; they were not with the horse at the moment, but they came in a minute or two, and said they had it in their possession two years, and bought it of a hawking saddler, but we knew we had had it within twelve months, because it was new when we lost it; we had used it in February - our saddler, knew it, and it answered the general pattern, of which we had thirty-eight pairs of hames.

JOHN GOUGH
. I cut the pattern of these hames, and they were sent to Birmingham to be made, and to have the rings and leather put together.

JOHN RICARDS
. I was in Pickford and Co's employ. I issued eleven sets of these hames, on the 13th of September, which was the first issue of them - there were none of these in use at that time.

GEORGE LEE
. I only know they were issued, and we commenced working with them on the 1st of October.

ISAAC NEALE
. I used to supply them with hames - these are not what I made.
JOHN SHEPHARD. I took one of the prisoners - they were held to bail.
NOT GUILTY .

267.
JAMES HARE
and
JOHN SMITH
were indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of December , 4 bushels of malt, value 25s., the goods of
Edward Jones
; and 1 sack, value 2s., the goods of
Henry Hole
.

RICHARD JONES. I am brother of Mr.
Edward Jones
, proprietor of the Hope Brewery, at Edmonton
. Last Sunday morning week we found the brewery broken open in the morning, and missed four bushels of malt, and a sack, which were the property of Mr.
Henry Hole
.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was it not in consequence of a letter from Mr. Jackson that the prisoners were taken up? A. Yes.

HENRY HOLE
. I lent twenty sacks to Mr. Jones - I have seen one of them since, at Mr. Jackson's - I was present when Hare was apprehended; he said he had found it in Islington.
Cross-examined. Q. How far is that from where it was stolen? A. About seven miles.

THOMAS JACKSON
. I am a corn-dealer, and live in Chichester-place, St. Pancras. On the Monday before the 10th of December, Smith the prisoner, called to inquire the price of malt between eleven and one o'clock; he went away - Hare then came to ask if I was a buyer of malt; Smith then came and brought a sack of malt which they both said they had found by the coach rank at Islington; I saw on the sack "Henry Hole, Edmonton," marked in red letters - I told them they had better go to the person whose name it bore, and tell him they had found it; they said they thought they should not get paid if they went, and asked me to pay their expences; I said, "Then write, or I will write for you, to save all trouble;" I took a piece of paper and wrote in their presence, and gave the letter to a man who came in on business - they saw what I did, and said they thought it was the best thing that could be done; they left the malt with me.

Cross-examined. Q. You wrote by their desire? A. Yes, and Mr. Jones came to town; the prisoners called frequently after I had written, to know if I had had an answer - and when Mr. Jones did come, I sent to the White Hart and one of the prisoners was there - he came directly, and the other soon after; I know the prisoners to be hackney coachmen - there was nothing to prevent their cutting the name out of the sack
NOT GUILTY .

268.
ANN SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of December , 1 sovereign, and 1 half-sovereign, the monies of
William Abel
, from his person .

WILLIAM ABEL. On the 12th of December I was in Hackney-road, Shoreditch
- I saw the prisoner, who followed me, took my arm, and took me up a dark street; I was not sober, but I knew what passed - she asked me to give her sixpence, which I did; she put her arm round me, and I lost a sovereign and a half. which were in a piece of printed paper in my left-hand breeches pocket - I missed them in three or four minutes, or it might be ten minutes. I cannot say exactly; I followed after the prisoner directly -I told her she had robbed me, and I took her by the arm, called the Policeman, and gave her in charge; she denied it - I told the Policeman, in her presence, that she had taken a sovereign and a half of mine.

FRANCIS FEATHERSTONE
. I am a Police-officer. I took the prisoner on the night in question; the prosecutor stated that he had lost a sovereign and half; I asked her what money she had in her pocket; she took out some halfpence and a sixpence, and said that was all she had about her I took her and searched her, and on unlacing her stays, a piece of paper dropped; I took it up, this is it - it is printed paper, and a sovereign and a half were in it.
Prisoner. I picked it up at my feet, wrapped up in the paper, I did not know what it was, but being distressed I put it inside my stays.

WILLIAM ABEL
re-examined. Q. You say you were intoxicated; now were your clothes in such a state that this might have fallen from your breeches pocket on the ground? A. No, my Lord, my clothes were not down at all, and that pocket was not unbuttoned; I was not so intoxicated as to be uncertain about it; it was about one o'clock in the morning - I had been at work from the dinner time before; I am aware that this is a very serious charge, but it was not possible for me to have dropped it.
FRANCIS FEATHERSTONE. The prosecutor was a little in liquor, but he seemed quite collected, and walked pretty well; he was in a state to know what he was about.

JURY to W. ABEL. Q. Was your sixpence in the same pocket with the sovereign and a half? A. No, it was not, I am sure; I did not open that pocket at all - when I saw her, I put my hand into that pocket, felt the money safe, and buttoned it again.

GUILTY . Aged 30. -
Transported for Life .

269.
WILLIAM ROBINSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of November , 1 shirt, value 4s., and 1 waistcoat, value 3s. , the goods of
Samuel Atkins
.

SARAH ATKINS
. I am the wife of Samuel Atkins - we live in New Gravel-lane, Shadwell
. The prisoner lodged in our house previous to the 1st of December, and left it that day - while he was there I missed a shirt and a waistcoat on the 30th of November; Mrs. Hunter produced some duplicates to me, in the prisoner's presence - in consequence of what I heard I spoke to the prisoner, and went and got the things out of pawn with the duplicates; among the rest was this shirt at Mr. Purser's, and this waistcoat at Mr. Lance's - Mr. Lance did not appear against the prisoner.
Prisoner. Q. Did not you promise that if I would go with you to Mr. Hunter, you would say no more about it. A. No - I said it would be better for him to own to it, and he owned to all the duplicates.

FRANCIS HUNTER
. I live at the sign of the Wheatsheaf in Wapping. The prisoner brought some duplicates to my bar, and told me to take care of them for him till he came from sea; I put them into my bar-drawer - I gave the same duplicates to my wife, and told her to give them to the prisoner or to Mrs. Atkins.
SARAH ATKINS. Mr. Hunter said, in the prisoner's presence, that he had given her the duplicates to take care of - he did not say any thing to that.

CAROLINE PURSER
. I am the wife of
Robert Purser
-- he lives at Limehouse-causeway. Mrs. Atkins took a shirt out of pawn at our house; I have the counterpart of the duplicate - they exactly correspond; it was pawned by a seafaring person, on the 12th of November, but I have no recollection of the person.

SARAH ATKINS. I am not sure whether the shirt had been up stairs or down, but it was in my house. and in my possession; I think it was where the prisoner could have access to it - the duplicate produced to me by Mr Hunter enabled me to get the waistcoat out of pawn; the prisoner went with me.

Prisoner's Defence. When I left Mr. Atkins' house, he said he was very sorry, and he would not say any thing about the business, provided I conducted myself better - I went to his house on the Wednesday following, to see how much I owed him, and if I could raise the money to pay him - he never offered to take me then; I went on the Saturday night, and he said there was a letter at his house for me, and if I would go all should be right - when I went the letter had no money in it, as I expected, and he gave charge of me.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Confined Six Months .

270.
ROBERT LANGGIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of December , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
James Volum
, from his person .

JAMES VOLUM
. I am a master-mariner , and live in Hermitage-street, between the London and St. Katharine-docks. On the 14th of December, at a quarter-past two o'clock, I was walking in High-street, Shadwell
- Mr. Palmer spoke to me, and I missed a handkerchief from my pocket. which I had felt safe about an hour before - this is it.

JOHN PALMER
. I am a cheesemonger. On the afternoon of the 14th of December I saw the prisoner and another lad following the prosecutor very close; I watched them, and saw the other draw the handkerchief from the pocket, and hand it to the prisoner; I took the handkerchief from a witness, and gave the prisoner to the Policeman - the other boy escaped; they were close together when it was taken.

DAVID MOSES
. I live in High-street. I was eating my dinner, and saw the prisoner run by - I immediately saw this handkerchief at the door; I took it up, and saw the prisoner in custody - I gave it to Mr. Palmer.

JOHN HENHAM
. I saw the prisoner running, and took him into custody; he said he was not the buy that took it.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going to my cousin's, and was not near the other lad; I happened to cross the road, this gentleman came up, and seized me by the collar - another boy ran by, and dropped the handkerchief; I said I had done nothing - I did not like to go with him.
GUILTY. Aged 16.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor .
Transported for Seven Years .

271.
MARTHA GALWAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of December , 1 watch, value 24s., and 2 seals, value 5s., the goods of
Thomas Medell
. from his person .

THOMAS MEDELL. I live in Crescent-place, Hackney-road, and am a carpenter . On Sunday night, the 5th of December, I went with my sister to John-place, Finsbury-market
