- she had not the key, and went to the prisoner, who lives next door, to try if her key would open it, but it would not - the door was at last burst open; the prisoner then asked me to make her an acknowledgment for the loan of her key, though it proved unsuccessful; I went into her house, and threw down a shilling - another woman was for a quartern of gin; the prisoner then proposed to me to stop all night, which I agreed to do; I went to bed, having put my clothes on a white table under the window - I had given her some money; and I left some money and a watch and seals in my pockets - I had looked at the watch at night, and replaced it into the fob of my trousers - about five o'clock in the morning I heard a noise of a person trying to get in at the street door; the prisoner got up, threw up the window, and saw a man; she said she would let him in she then went down as she was, with the exception of putting on a gown, and let him in; while she was gone I looked at my trousers, and the watch was gone - the prisoner remained down stairs about two hours; the man then went away, and she came up stairs; there are but two rooms in the house - I asked her about the watch when she came up; she said she knew nothing about it, and showed me her room. but there was nothing there -I went out about eight o'clock, and got the Policeman, who took her, but the watch has not been found; it was a metal watch, worth about 25s., and two gold seals worth 5s.; I was a little the worse for liquor, but I can undertake to say that I looked at my watch and put it into my fob safe, and I could tell exactly the time.

Prisoner's Defence. I never saw a watch - I asked him for money in the morning, and he would not give me any - he said he had lost a watch; he brought a Policeman, who searched the house - I heard the knock at the door, and came down in my night-gown; the Policeman came before I was dressed, and I was taken to the station - We had been to Mr. Alabaster's public-house, and he would make me drink something.

THOMAS MEDELL
. I certainly had a watch, and pulled it out at her house.
Prisoner. Q. What did you say? A. I did not make any observation - I was sober; it was with a great deal of persuasion I was induced to stop there.

THOMAS DRAPER
. The prosecutor lodged with me -I saw him with a watch, on the 5th of December, about half-past nine o'clock, when he left to go with his sister; I was at Worship-street, and heard the prisoner say to somebody under the gateway, that she had had the watch, and he might do what he pleased.

Prisoner. Q. Did you see the prosecutor go with me to the public-house? A. No, I went to your house, and you denied his being there - you opened the back door, and said I might search the house if I liked; he was quite capable of taking care of himself.

JOHN SHEPHERD
. I am a Police-officer, I took the prisoner on the charge of stealing the watch - she denied having seen it; I searched but found nothing.
GUILTY of stealing only . Aged 24.
Transported for Seven Years .

272.
THOMAS JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of December , 6 quires of printed paper, value 10s. , the goods of
William Henry McQueen
.

WILLIAM HENRY MCQUEEN
. I live at No. 72, Newman-street.
Henry Carman
is in my service.

HENRY CARMAN
. I live in Foley-street, and am errand-boy to the prosecutor - he is a copper-plate printer . About six o'clock in the evening, on the 4th of Decemher, he gave me a book, containing 1500 letter-press sheets, to take to Mr. Jewel, a hot-presser, in Peterborough-court, Fleet-street; in going along I set my books down at the corner of Southampton-street, Holborn
- I turned to look at a person, and when I turned again, I saw the prisoner running away with my books; he had them on his shoulder - I ran after him, and took them from him; I did after that lose sight of him for a moment, but when I saw him again, he was still running - he ran down to Princes-street, where I lost sight of him for about two minutes; I had before that cried Stop thief! and he was stopped by a Policeman, who was but a short distance when the books were taken - I at once knew him to be the same person; they were worth 50s.
Prisoner. You said 5l. at Bow-street. Witness. No, I said I did not know, and master said 50s.

FRANCIS REYNOLDS
. I am a Policeman. About seven o'clock on the night of the 4th of December, I heard Stop thief! called, and saw the prisoner running - a man put his foot out and threw him down, and I took him; he had been running very fast - he begged very hard to be let go; I took him above two hundred yards from where the books were lost.

COURT to
HENRY CARMAN
. Q. How many yards do you think it was before you saw him again after you lost sight of him? A. About a hundred.

Prisoner's Defence. I had been out of work eight months, was walking along Holborn, and this paper stood at the corner of Princes-street - a gentleman respectably dressed asked me to carry it to Southampton-street, he gave me 6d. and I showed it to the Magistrate.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Seven Years .

THE KING v.
JOSEPH MATHER
.

14.
JOSEPH MATHER
, who was convicted in July Session of uttering a forged acceptance, (see Crowder, Mayor, page 568) being called to the bar, Mr. Justice Littledale proceeded to deliver the decision of the Judges upon his case, as follows: - "This was an indictment against Joseph Mather for
forging an acceptance to a bill of exchange . The prisoner was convicted in July Session, before Mr. Justice
James Parke
, on an indictment, charging him with uttering and publishing as true, &c.; the indictment was founded on 7 Geo. 2, c. 22, sec. 1 - it was stated that at the last Spring assizes at York, Mr. Baron Hullock had held that this Statute was in this respect repealed by 45 Geo. 3, c. 89, sec. 1, and that the proper form of indictment was on the latter Statute, which makes it an offence to "offer, dispose of, and put away," in consequence of that decision Mr. Justice
James Parke
directed the judgment to be respited, and reserved the question for the consideration of the Judges: Mr. Justice
James Parke
has since found that in Fauntleroy's case (2 Buigh, page 413) the verdict was entered on the Counts, charging the prisoner with "uttering and publishing as true," a forged deed, and no objection was taken on this ground. The case has been submitted to the consideration of several of the judges, who unanimously resolved that the conviction was proper; and Mr. Justice Bosanquet informed the Court that the point had been decided by three Judges at the Old Bailey.
The Number of Prisoners committed for Trial at the present Session, was 328.
Discharged by Proclestion..... 88
Convlcted..... 242
Of whom 14 have Received Beatence of Death
21..... Transportation for Life.
125 carried up.
125 brought up.
108 have been imprisoned for various terms, Whipped or Fined.
9 Judgement Respited.
